ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
§ 5-1 LICENSE - REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct or operate any theatrical, circus, carnival,
exhibition or public amusement of any kind without having first obtained a
license as is required in this chapter.
(1929 Code, § 335)
§ 5-2 SAME - APPLICATION.
   Applications for licenses required by §
5-1 shall be made to the village manager and shall designate the place where
the amusement is to be held, and the nature and type thereof. Each application
shall be accompanied by a payment of the fee required, except as is otherwise
provided, and no license shall be issued until the fee is paid.
(1929 Code, § 348)
Cross-reference:
   As to licenses and permits generally, see
ch. 22
§ 5-3 SAME - FEES.
   (a)   The fee for licenses required by §
5-1 shall be as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
   (b)   The owner or manager of any building who shall procure an annual
license as is required by §
5-1 shall be permitted to conduct amusements and shows, except races and
athletic contests, throughout the year on the premises for which the license
was issued without the payment of a daily fee.
(Ord. No. 80-10-1610; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 5-4 SEATING CAPACITY; STANDING DURING PERFORMANCES.
   It shall be unlawful to allow in theatres or opera houses more persons than
can be accommodated by the seating capacity thereof. It shall be unlawful for
any person to remain standing or to permit any person to remain standing during
the performance of an amusement licensed by this article that is conducted or
displayed in a building or hall.
(1929 Code, § 351)
§ 5-5 OBEDIENCE TO CHAPTER, ETC.
   Every person licensed as provided by §
5-1 shall obey all the provisions in this chapter in addition to all other
provisions that may relate to amusement or theatrical licenses or the premises
occupied.
(1929 Code, § 336)
§ 5-6 AUDIENCE TO BE ORDERLY; FIRE, ETC., RISKS.
   (a)   The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical shall be orderly and
quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such
amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any
such amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or
other risks.
(1929 Code, § 337)
Cross-reference:
   As to fire prevention generally, see
ch. 17
§ 5-7 INSPECTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the chief of police and fire chief each to see that
every exhibition, amusement, theatrical or other public show or amusement is
inspected by a member of the police and fire departments to insure conformity
with the provisions concerning such amusements.
(1929 Code, § 338)
§ 5-8 INDECENT SHOWS, ETC.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to present, exhibit, conduct, produce or
in any manner assist in or take part in any indecent or immoral show,
theatrical, play, motion picture, exhibition or other form of public amusement
or show.
(1929 Code, § 339)
Charter reference:
   For charter provision as to authority of village with regard to prohibiting,
etc., indecent exposure, etc., see char.,
art. IV, § 21
§ 5-9 EXHIBITION OF CRIMINALS, ETC.
   It shall be unlawful to exhibit any criminal or the body of any criminal, or
any person who shall have become notorious because of the commission of a
crime, in any theatrical, exhibit, carnival or other public amusement.
(1929 Code, § 340)
§ 5-10 SHOWS, ETC., TENDING TO CAUSE RIOTS, ETC.
   It shall be unlawful to present any public amusement or show of any kind
that tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or public
disturbance.
(1929 Code, § 341)
§ 5-11 APPROVAL OF PREMISES BY DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS.
   No license shall be issued to any person to produce, present, conduct,
operate or offer for gain or profit any theatricals, shows or amusements until
the director of public works shall have certified in writing that the room or
place where it is proposed to produce, present, conduct, operate or offer such
theatricals, shows or amusements complies in every respect with the building
code and other ordinances of the village.
(1929 Code, § 342)
Cross-reference:
   As to director of public works generally, see §§
2-74 to
2-76
§ 5-12 LIGHTING OF PREMISES GENERALLY.
   Every portion of any building or structure in which theatricals, moving
picture shows and amusements are offered, operated, presented or exhibited for
gain or profit devoted to the use or accommodation of the public, and all
outlets therefrom leading to the street, including all open courts, corridors,
stairways, exits and emergency exit stairways, shall be well and properly
lighted with electric lights during every performance, and shall remain lighted
until the entire audience has left the premises.
(1929 Code, § 343)
§ 5-13 LIGHTING OF EXITS; EXIT SIGNS.
   (a)   All stairways and corridors in every building or structure in which
theatricals, shows and amusements are offered, operated, presented or exhibited
for gain shall be supplied with a supplemental lighting system of electricity
or gas, and such system shall be independent of all other lights in such
building or structure and shall be in operation during the entire period that
such building or structure is open to the public and until the entire audience
has left the building.
   (b)   The word "Exit" shall appear in letters at least six inches high over
the opening of every means of egress from such building or structure, and a red
light shall be kept burning over such sign at all times at which the building
is open to the public.
(1929 Code, § 344)
§ 5-14 OBSTRUCTION OF EXITS, PASSAGEWAYS, ETC.
   (a)   No exit door or gate in any place in which theatricals, shows or
amusements are offered, operated, presented or exhibited for gain shall be
locked or fastened in any manner during the entire time that such place of
amusement is open to the public.
   (b)   All aisles, passageways, corridors and exits of all such places of
amusement shall be kept free from camp stools, stairs, sofas, draperies and
other obstructions and no person shall be allowed to stand in or occupy any of
such aisles, passageways, corridors or exits during any performance.
(1929 Code, § 345)
Cross-reference:
   As to obstructing exits, etc., in motion picture theatres, see §
5-31
ARTICLE II. BILLIARDS AND POOL
§ 5-15 LICENSE - REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall operate, maintain or conduct a billiard, pool, bagatelle or
pigeon hole table open to the public without having obtained a license therefor
as provided by this article. Every person keeping for use any billiard table,
pool table, bagatelle or pigeon hole table or any other tables or implements
for similar purposes and open to the public shall pay a license fee of $10 per
year for each billiard or other such table he or she may keep.
(1929 Code, § 353)
Cross-reference:
   As to licenses and permits generally, see
ch. 22
§ 5-16 SAME - GOOD CHARACTER OF APPLICANT A PREREQUISITE TO ISSUANCE;
INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT, ETC.
   No license required by this article shall be issued to any person who is not
a person of good character. Upon receipt of an application for such a license,
the village manager shall cause an investigation to be made of the character of
the applicant; if the result of such investigation is not favorable, or if the
village manager is not convinced of the good character of the applicant, he or
she shall return the fee for license.
(1929 Code, § 354)
§ 5-17 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   All pool or billiard halls open to the public in this village are hereby
required to be closed for all purposes and cease doing business of any kind
whatsoever at 12:00 midnight and they shall remain so closed and no business
whatever shall be done therein until 5:00 a.m. the following morning. No such
place shall be kept open for business on Sundays.
(1929 Code, § 355)
§ 5-18 CONDUCT OF PATRONS, GAMBLING, ETC.
   Persons frequenting any pool or billiard hall in the village shall conduct
themselves in a quiet manner. It shall be unlawful to gamble or to permit any
gambling in any billiard or poolroom. It shall be unlawful to use or to permit
the use of any boisterous or profane language in any billiard or poolroom.
(1929 Code, § 356)
Cross-reference:
   As to gambling generally, see §§
24-23 to
24-26
§ 5-19 MINORS UNDER 16 YEARS OF AGE.
   Minors under age of 16 years shall under no circumstances frequent, loiter,
go or remain in any pool hall or billiard parlor within the village at any
time, unless it be upon some lawful errand and such minor is sent by the
direction and with the consent and knowledge of the parent, guardian or other
person having the legal custody and control of such minor. Proprietors of pool
halls or billiard parlors shall not permit such minors under the age of 16
years to frequent, loiter or remain within such pool halls or billiard parlors.
(1929 Code, § 357)
Cross-reference:
   As to minors under 16 years of age in bowling alleys, see §
5-24
   As to sale, etc., of weapons to minors, see §
24-50
   As to sale of cigarettes to minors under 18 years of age, see §
24-8
§ 5-20 INSPECTIONS BY POLICE.
   Any member of the police department shall have free access to all parts of
any premises used for a pool or billiard room at all reasonable hours for the
purposes of making inspections to see to the enforcement of the provisions of
this article.
(1929 Code, § 358)
Cross-reference:
   As to police department generally, see §§
2-84 to
2-96
ARTICLE III. BOWLING ALLEYS
§ 5-21 LICENSE - REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   No person shall operate, maintain or conduct a bowling or pin alley open to
the public for which a fee is charged without having first obtained a license
therefor as provided by this article. All applications for such a license shall
be made in writing to the village manager and shall state therein the intended
location of the place of business and the number of alleys to be used therein.
(1929 Code, § 360)
Cross-reference:
   As to licenses and permits generally, see
ch. 22
§ 5-22 SAME - FEE.
   The annual license fee for any license required by §
5-21 shall be $100.
(1929 Code, § 361) (Ord. No. 1223)
§ 5-23 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (a)   All bowling or pin alleys open to the public are hereby required to be
closed for all purposes and to cease doing business of any kind whatsoever at
12:00 midnight and they shall remain so closed and no business whatever be done
therein until 5:00 a.m. the next morning.
   (b)   All places of business licensed under the provisions of this article
are required to be closed for all purposes at 11:00 p.m. every Saturday night
and shall remain so closed until 5:00 a.m. on the following Monday morning.
(1929 Code, §§ 364, 365)
§ 5-24 MINORS UNDER 16 YEARS OF AGE.
   It shall be unlawful for the proprietor of any place of business licensed
under the provision of this article, or any person in charge thereof, to allow
any minor under the age of 16 years to frequent, loiter, go or remain in any
such place of business at any time, unless it be upon some lawful errand and
such minor is sent by the direction and with the consent and knowledge of the
parent, guardian or other person having the legal custody and control of such
minor.
(1929 Code, § 362)
Cross-reference:
   As to minors under 16 years of age in poolrooms, etc., see §
5-19
ARTICLE IV. MOTION PICTURES
§ 5-25 LICENSE TO OPERATE MOTION PICTURE PROJECTOR - REQUIRED.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any moving picture
projecting machine or device in any public place or any place where the public
is admitted within the village, unless such person so operating the same shall
have first obtained, and be at such time the proper holder of, a license
therefor as a moving picture projector operator, as set forth in this article.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to employ, engage or use a moving
picture projector operator who shall not have prior thereto procured, or who
shall not at that time be the proper holder of a license, as provided for by
this article.
(1929 Code, § 372)
Cross-reference:
   As to licenses and permits generally, see
ch. 22
§ 5-26 SAME - QUALIFICATIONS OF OPERATOR; DURATION.
   (a)   A license to operate a moving picture projecting machine or device may
be issued to any person applying therefor who shall be over the age of 21
years; provided, that the board of trustees or the village president shall,
upon an examination of such applicant, find the applicant competent, or shall
find the applicant to be the holder in good standing of a license issued by the
City of Chicago or some other municipality of the state by which an examination
of such applicants is required; provided, further, that no license shall be
issued to any person if in the opinion of the board of trustees, after due
examination by them, such applicant therefor shall be determined by them to be
irresponsible or incompetent.
   (b)   Each license issued under the provisions of this article shall be
valid for the period of one year from its date of issue only, but may be
revoked at any time during such period.
(1929 Code, § 373)
§ 5-27 SAME - FEE.
   No license shall be issued to any person under this article as a motion
picture projecting machine operator except upon the payment, which sum shall be
paid to the village clerk for the general uses of the village upon the issuance
of such license as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine
Schedule.
(1929 Code, § 384) (Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 5-28 THEATRE PROJECTOR PERMIT; FEE.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, manage or control the
operation of any moving picture projecting machine or device, where an
admission fee is charged, and the same is operated for the purpose of profit,
unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and issued by order of the
board of trustees, which permit shall state upon its face the location of the
moving picture projecting machine or device to be operated, that the same is
issued under the conditions specified in this article, and that the same shall
be valid for the period of one year after date of issue.
   (b)   Such permit when duly issued shall authorize the holder thereof to
operate; provided, that he or she shall also be the holder of a license duly
issued under the provisions of this article or shall cause to be operated by
the holder of a duly issued license a moving picture machine or device for such
purpose and for the period of one year, subject, however, to all the terms and
conditions of this article. Such permit shall be issued and any renewal thereof
shall be issued only upon the payment of a fee per annum for each seat provided
in the theatre, room, hall or auditorium in which such moving picture machine
or device is to be operated as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and
Fine Schedule.
(1929 Code, § 385) (Ord. No. 1188; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 5-29 PROHIBITED PICTURES.
   It shall be unlawful to offer or present any motion picture that has a
tendency to cause a riot or public disturbance, or any immoral, indecent or
blasphemous pictures or performances or picture that might suggest or incite to
crime.
(1929 Code, § 374) (Ord. No. 1188)
Cross-reference:
   As to indecent shows, etc., generally see §
5-8
   As to obscene and indecent pictures, books, etc., see §
24-40
§ 5-30 CROWDING IN THEATRES.
   It shall be unlawful to permit any person, except ushers or other employees,
to remain standing in a hall or room in which a motion picture is presented,
during the time of such performance, or for any such person to remain standing
therein at such at time. It shall be unlawful to admit to any such hall or room
more persons than can be accommodated by the seating arrangement for such
premises.
(Ord. No. 1188)
§ 5-31 OBSTRUCTING EXITS, ETC.
   It shall be unlawful to obstruct or permit the obstruction of any aisles,
corridors or exits leading from any room or enclosure in which a motion picture
performance is being given.
(Ord. No. 1188)
Cross-reference:
   As to obstruction of exits, passageways, etc., in places of amusements, see
§
5-14
§ 5-32 PROJECTION BOOTHS.
   (a)   Moving picture projecting machine and devices temporarily installed in
assembly rooms or halls shall be placed in an enclosure or booth made of
suitable fireproof material, or lined or covered with suitable fireproof
material. Such enclosure or booth shall be thoroughly ventilated and large
enough for the operator to walk freely on either side of and back of the
machine. All openings into this enclosure or booth shall be arranged so as to
be entirely closed by doors or shutters of like material and held normally
closed by springs, hinges or other devices. All other provisions of the
building code of the village, as amended, and future amendments thereto, shall
apply to and govern the operation and use of such booths.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person at any time to smoke, or to carry
or use lighted matches or to use fire or an open light, or oil, gas or
illuminating lamps in an operating booth while any motion picture projecting
device is being operated, or during the time any audience is in the building;
provided, that such lights as may be necessary for use in operating such
machine only may be used.
(1929 Code, §§ 382, 383)
§ 5-33 HOURS OF BUSINESS FOR THEATRES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause or permit to be
operated any motion picture projecting machine, device, show or entertainment
for profit under this article before 1:00 p.m. on Sundays, or to keep the
premises open in which the same may be or are operated later than 1:00 a.m. of
any weekday or Sunday.
(1929 Code, § 386) (Ord. No. 1188)
§ 5-34 ASSIGNMENT OF LICENSES AND PERMITS.
   (a)   No license for the operation of a moving picture projecting machine or
device shall be assigned or transferred to any person.
   (b)   No permit for the operation of any moving picture projecting machine
or device, show or entertainment shall be assigned or transferred to any
person, whatever, unless the same shall have first been authorized or permitted
by action of the president and board of trustees of the village.
(1929 Code, § 387)
§ 5-35 VIOLATIONS OF ARTICLE.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished
as provided in §
16-1. In addition thereto the president of the village may revoke the permits
or licenses or any of them issued under this article to such person.
(1929 Code, § 388)
ARTICLE V. PUBLIC DANCE HALLS
§ 5-36 LICENSE - REQUIRED; ISSUANCE.
   No person shall operate or conduct a public dance hall without having
obtained a license to do so. No such license shall be issued except on order of
the president and board of trustees.
(1929 Code, § 389)
Cross-reference:
   As to licenses and permits generally, see
ch. 22
§ 5-37 SAME - APPLICATION; FEES.
   (a)   Application for licenses required by this article shall be made to the
village manager, and shall designate the place, premises or building intended
to be occupied.
   (b)   The fee for a license to operate or conduct a public dance hall shall
be as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule. No such
license shall be issued without the payment of the fee.
(1929 Code, § 390) (Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 5-38 INSPECTIONS; EXITS.
   (a)   The inspections to be made under the supervision of the chief of
police and the fire chief provided for in §
5-7 shall be made of the premises occupied by any person licensed under this
article.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful to conduct a public dance in any hall that is not
equipped with sufficient and adequate exits, and no hall or building that is
not equipped with at least two exits of four feet or more in width shall be
used for a public dance in the village.
(1929 Code, § 391)
ARTICLE VI. MEETINGS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY
§ 5-39 APPROVAL OR PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person or group of persons shall hold any meeting or event of any kind on
village owned property (including village streets or rights-of-way) or within
village owned buildings without first having obtained approval or a permit from
the village manager or the manager's designee.
(Ord. No. 70-11-1480, § 1; Ord. No. 06-13-3155)
§ 5-40 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   (a)   Information. A person seeking issuance of a permit hereunder shall
file an application with the village manager. The application shall state:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;
      (2)   The name and address of the person or persons, corporation or
association sponsoring the activity if any;
      (3)   The day and hours for which the permit is desired;
      (4)   The village property for which such permit is desired;
      (5)   An estimate of the anticipated attendance;
      (6)   An agreement to indemnify and save harmless the village against any
and all liability, loss, damages, costs or expense which it may incur, suffer
or be required to pay by reason of the issuance of such permit and the use of
the public property; and
      (7)   Any other information that the village manager shall find
reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should
issue hereunder.
   (b)   Standards for issuance of permit. The village manager shall issue a
permit hereunder when he or she finds:
      (1)   The proposed activity or use of the village property will not
unreasonably interfere with or detract from any general public enjoyment of
such village property;
      (2)   The proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with
or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare and safety;
      (3)   The proposed activity or use is not reasonably anticipated to
incite violence or disorderly conduct;
      (4)   The proposed activity will not entail unusual, extraordinary or
burdensome expense or police operation by the village; and
      (5)   The facilities desired have not been reserved for other use at the
day and hour required in the application.
   (c)   Effect of permit. A permittee shall be bound by all applicable
ordinances fully as if the same were inserted in such permit.
   (d)   Revocation. The village manager shall have the authority to revoke a
permit upon a finding of violation of any ordinance or upon good cause shown.
(Ord. No. 70-11-1480, § 1)
§ 5-41 BOND; REIMBURSEMENT OF COSTS.
   (a)   In addition to the agreement for indemnification contained in the
application for a permit, the village manager may in his or her discretion
require the applicant to furnish a bond in an amount and with or without surety
as determined by the village manager in the exercise of his or her sound
discretion if the manager determines such bond or surety is in the best
interest of the health, safety and welfare of the village based on the size,
scope and nature of the applicant's proposed activity or use; provided,
however, that neither the purpose of the meeting or event nor the applicant
shall be considered in determining whether such financial security shall be
required.
   (b)   To the extent village personnel, equipment or supplies will be
required in connection with the proposed activity or use, the applicant shall
be required to reimburse the village for the costs of such personnel, equipment
or supplies in accordance with generally applicable rates established by the
village manager from time to time.
(Ord. No. 06-13-3155)
ARTICLE VII. COMMERCIAL FILMING OR TAPING ON PUBLIC PROPERTY
(Ord. No. 96-4-2000)
§ 5-42 PERMIT - REQUIRED.
   No person or group of persons shall use any street, right-of-way or public
building, equipment or personnel for commercial use in the filming or taping of
movies, television programs, commercials or training films and related
activities without first having obtained a permit from the village manager.
(Ord. No. 96-4-2000)
§ 5-43 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   (a)   Information. A person seeking issuance of a permit pursuant to this
article shall file an application with the village manager at least 48 hours
before the desired production date. The application shall state:
      (1)   The title of the production to be filmed or taped;
      (2)   The name, address and phone number of the applicant production
company;
      (3)   The name and phone number of the producer and the director;
      (4)   The name, phone number and address of the location coordinator and,
if such location coordinator does not reside within 50 miles of the Village of
Glencoe, the name and phone number of the Illinois Film Office representative
for the production;
      (5)   The type of production;
      (6)   The production schedule;
      (7)   The proposed location(s) of production;
      (8)   A general description of the script or content of the production,
as well as a description of any proposed special effects for the production;
      (9)   The anticipated need of village personnel, equipment and or
property;
      (10)   An agreement to indemnify and hold harmless the village and its
corporate authorities, officers, officials, boards, commissions, employees,
attorneys, agents and representatives from and against any loss, damage,
expense, claims, costs of every nature and kind arising out of or in connection
with any filming or taping or by reason of issuance of any permit, or the use
of public property, or the assistance of village personnel; and
      (11)   Any other information that the village manager shall find
reasonably necessary to determine whether permit should issue hereunder.
   (b)   Certificate of insurance.
      (1)   The applicant shall attach to such application a certificate of
insurance, naming the Village of Glencoe and its corporate authorities,
officers, officials, boards, commissions, employees, attorneys, agents and
representatives as additional insured, in the amount of $1,000,000 general
liability, including bodily injury and property damages; and automobile
liability (if applicable) in the amount of $1,000,000 including bodily injury
and property damage. Such certificate shall include the following language:
"The Village of Glencoe, its corporate authorities, officers, officials,
boards, commissions, employees, attorneys, agents and representatives are made
additional insured with respect to any and all claims which arise out of, or
are in any way related to, the operations of the film maker while present in
the Village of Glencoe."
      (2)   The applicant shall also attach to such application proof that the
appropriate worker's compensation and employer's liability insurance have been
provided for the employees of the filming company.
   (c)   Report on discussions with property owners in the affected
neighborhoods. The applicant shall provide a short written description of and
schedule for the proposed production to the owners and residents of each
property in the affected neighborhood (as defined by boundaries set by the
village manager). The applicant shall talk with owners and residents of all
such property and submit as part of the application a report noting any owner
or resident's reaction along with the addresses and phone numbers of all such
property owners and residents.
   (d)   Vehicles and equipment. The applicant must submit a report listing the
number of vehicles and types of equipment to be used during the production
including their proposed parking locations. Such locations are subject to the
specific approval of the village manager in order to maintain traffic safety.
   (e)   Effect of permit. A permittee shall fully comply with all applicable
ordinances as if the same were fully set forth in such permit.
   (f)   Time period of permit. The authorization granted pursuant to and in
accordance with the application shall be for a specific time period to be
determined by the village.
(Ord. No. 96-4-2000)
§ 5-44 APPLICATION FEE.
   The nonrefundable application fee for the permit to conduct professional
filming or taping or other related activities designated in this article shall
be as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule. The fee
can be reduced or waived at the discretion of the village manager.
(Ord. No. 96-4-2000; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 5-45 RIGHTS OF THE VILLAGE.
   As a condition of any permit granted pursuant to this article, the applicant
shall agree that the village may in its discretion:
   (a)   Exercise control over or otherwise regulate or restrict the use of
public streets, rights-of-way and buildings of the village during the time of
production;
   (b)   Exercise control over or otherwise regulate or restrict the hours of
production and the general location of the production;
   (c)   Prohibit all filming or taping or order cessation of filming or taping
and the revocation of the permit if determined to be hazardous to the public
health, safety and welfare or upon a finding of violation of any ordinance or
any condition or provision of the permit; and
   (d)   Inspect all structures and/or devices and equipment to be used in
connection with the filming and taping.
(Ord. No. 96-4-2000)
§ 5-46 RATES FOR USE OF VILLAGE PERSONNEL, EQUIPMENT AND PROPERTY.
   (a)   Personnel. The producer shall pay for the costs of any public safety,
public works or other village personnel assigned to the project (whether
specifically requested by the producer or not) at a rate established by the
village manager.
   (b)   Equipment. The remuneration rates for the use of any village equipment
shall be established on a case-by-case basis.
   (c)   Property. Based upon the extent of the use of village property, the
producer shall reimburse the village for using village property and the
inconvenience resulting from such use. Reimbursement shall be set forth in the
village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule and shall depend on the level of
disruption caused by the commercial filming or taping.
   (d)   Payment. All checks should be made payable to “Village of Glencoe.”
Anticipated fees shall be paid in advance of production.
   (e)   Restoration. The producer shall be responsible to restore all public
property or village equipment to substantially the same condition that such
property or equipment was in prior to its use for the production.
(Ord. No. 96-4-2000; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 5-47 BOND.
   In addition to the agreement for indemnification contained in the
application for a permit, the village manager may in his or her discretion
require the applicant to furnish a bond in order to protect adequately the
interests of the village and its residents. The terms and amount of any such
bond shall be determined by the village manager in the exercise of his or her
sound discretion.
(Ord. No. 96-4-2000)
ARTICLE VIII. SPECIAL EVENTS
(Ord. No. 06-13-3155)
§ 5-48 DEFINITION OF SPECIAL EVENT.
   (a)   For purposes of this article, the term SPECIAL EVENT shall mean any
activity or use that is not subject to a permit pursuant to article VI or VII
of this chapter and either:
      (1)   Requires the use or assistance of, or imposes an impact on, any
village property, equipment, or personnel to an extent greater than is
customary in the ordinary course of village business;
      (2)   Involves the use of or impact on village streets or sidewalks in a
manner that would exceed normal use or travel on such streets or sidewalks;
      (3)   Involve a gathering of more than 100 people, other than gatherings
at a religious congregation or other place designed and intended for assembly
purposes and permitted under the village zoning code;
      (4)   Involves a gathering of more than 50 people at a dwelling for an
activity or use that assesses a charge or fee in connection with participation
in or attendance at such activity or use, or is organized or intended for the
purpose of raising funds;
      (5)   Involves the organized transport of persons from parking areas
within the village to sites either within or outside the village; or
      (6)   Is classified as a temporary use under subsection 5-102D1, 5-102D2,
5-102D5 or 5-102D6 of the village zoning code.
   (b)   Notwithstanding the foregoing, the following events shall not be
considered "special events:"
      (1)   A visit or appearance of the President or Vice-President of the
United States provided that the visit or appearance is for official business
and is open to the general public;
      (2)   A visit or appearance by the Governor of the State of Illinois
provided that the visit or appearance is for official business and is open to
the general public;
      (3)   A visit or appearance by an incumbent United States Senator elected
by the voters of the State of Illinois, provided that the visit or appearance
is for official business and is open to the general public;
      (4)   A visit or appearance by a member of the United States House of
Representatives elected by the voters of the Congressional District in which
the village is located, provided that the visit or appearance is for official
business and is open to the general public; and
      (5)   An activity or event that occurs outside the corporate limits of
the village, for which village personnel, services and/or resources are
provided pursuant to a mutual aid agreement, other intergovernmental agreement,
or a custom and practice of intergovernmental cooperation in which the
participating municipalities do not charge each other for services provided.
(Ord. No. 06-13-3155)
§ 5-49 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct a special event without first having made
application for and been issued a special event permit from the village in
accordance with the special event policy adopted by the village board, as it
may be amended from time to time.
(Ord. No. 06-13-3155)
§ 5-50 PERMIT FEE; SECURITY; REIMBURSEMENT OF COSTS.
   The permit fee for a special event, as well as any requirement for the
depositing of financial security or reimbursement of costs, shall be as set
forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
(Ord. No. 06-13-3155; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 5-51 COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS.
   Under no circumstance shall any use or activity be permitted as a special
event that is otherwise prohibited under the village zoning code or any other
federal, state or local ordinance, rule or regulation.
(Ord. No. 06-13-3155)

ARTICLE I. ANIMAL CARE AND CONTROL
§ 6-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section.
   ACCESSORY ANIMAL. A certain class of animal that is uncommon in residential
areas and that, if kept improperly, would be detrimental to the public health,
safety, comfort, convenience, and general welfare.
   ANIMAL. A living creature, domestic or wild, but does not include humans.
   AT LARGE. An animal which is off the premises of the owner and which is
neither in an enclosed motor vehicle nor, while on a leash, under the immediate
control of a responsible person.
   ATTACK. When an animal, without provocation, makes actual physical contact
with another animal or person that includes, but is not limited to, biting,
scratching or clawing.
   DOG. Both male and female dogs.
   LEASH. A leash, cord, chain or similar device.
   OWNER. Any person owning, keeping or harboring an animal.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 71-10-1490; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1; Ord. No.
2001-19-3036; Ord. No. 2022-09-3529, § 2)
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to domestic animals running at large, see Ill. Rev. Stat.,
ch. 8, § 359
§ 6-2 OWNER'S DUTY TO CONTROL ANIMALS.
   Animal care and control is the responsibility of the owner. An owner of any
animal shall be in violation of this section in the event such animal shall:
   (a)   Be at large;
   (b)   Chase a vehicle in any manner;
   (c)   Put another animal or person in imminent danger of being attacked;
   (d)   Attack persons in any manner;
   (e)   Attack other animals, including dogs, in any manner;
   (f)   Damage property other than the owner's; or
   (g)   Make excess noises, including barking, so as to disturb the peace and
quiet.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 71-10-1490; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1; Ord. No.
2001-19-3036)
§ 6-3 GUIDE DOGS.
   The provisions of §§
6-4 and
6-5 are inapplicable to guide dogs for the handicapped.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 71-10-1490; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1; Ord. No.
2001-19-3036)
§ 6-4 ANIMALS PROHIBITED ON BEACH.
   No animal shall be permitted, even though on a leash, to be on the public
beach from May 15 through September 15 of each year.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547)
§ 6-5 ANIMALS PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN PUBLIC PLACES.
   No animal shall be permitted, even though on a leash, to be in or enter upon
any school, school grounds, church, temple or public hall at any time. No
animal shall be permitted, even though on a leash, to be in or enter upon any
public garage, gas station, restaurant, ice cream parlor, soft drink parlor,
office, store (excluding pet shop), market or confectionery shop anywhere
within the village during the time that such place is open for public business.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1; Ord. 2001-19-3036)
§ 6-6 UNLEASHED DOGS PROHIBITED ON PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   No animal shall be permitted, except on a leash, to use or be upon any
public street, sidewalk, parkway or public place.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1; Ord. 2001-19-3036)
§ 6-7 CONTROL OF ANIMALS ON OWNER'S PROPERTY.
   No owner of an animal shall fail to control such animal on the owner's
property through the means of a leash, fence or the immediate control of a
responsible person to whose hand or voice commands the animal is obedient.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-8 CONTROL OF ANIMALS IN HEAT.
   No owner of an animal shall permit such animal to disturb the peace and
quiet of any neighborhood by attracting other animals to the owner's premises.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-9 CERTAIN ANIMALS PROHIBITED.
   No horse, cow, hog, sheep, goat, goose or duck nor any animal, the
possession or keeping of which is prohibited by applicable state or federal law
or regulation, shall be kept on private property within the village.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1; Ord. 2001-19-3036; Ord. No.
2022-09-3529, § 2)
§ 6-10 ANIMAL CARE.
   No owner shall fail to provide his or her animals with sufficient food and
wholesome food and water, proper shelter and protection from the weather,
veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering and inhumane care and
treatment.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 72-4-1496; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-11 ANIMAL LITTER ON OWNER'S PREMISES.
   No owner shall allow an accumulation of animal feces in any yard, pen or
premises in or upon which the owner's animal shall be confined or kept so that
such accumulation becomes offensive to those residing in the vicinity or a
health hazard to such animal.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-12 CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.
   No persons shall beat, cruelly ill-treat, torment, overload, overwork or
otherwise abuse an animal, or cause, instigate or permit any combat between
animals or animals and humans.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 72-4-1496; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-13 ABANDONING OF ANIMALS.
   No person shall abandon any animal owned or possessed by that person.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-14 KEEPING DISEASED ANIMALS.
   No persons shall keep any animal that is known to be infected with any
disease transmissible to other animals or man, including severe parasitism,
unless such animal shall be confined in such a manner as not to expose other
animals or humans to such disease.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-15 DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMAL AT LARGE.
   No person shall permit any dangerous or vicious animal of any kind to be at
large within the village.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-16 MOTORISTS' DUTY TOWARDS ANIMALS.
   No person shall willfully injure or run down with a vehicle any animal. Any
person who kills or injures an animal while driving a vehicle shall stop at the
scene of the accident and render such assistance as practicable, shall make a
reasonable effort to locate and identify himself or herself to the owner or any
person having custody of the animal, and shall report the accident immediately
to the public safety department.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1; Ord. No. 2001-19-3036)
§ 6-17 POISONING ANIMALS.
   No person shall expose any known poisonous substance, whether mixed with
food or not, so that the same shall be liable to be eaten by an animal;
provided that it shall not be unlawful for a person to expose on their private
property common rat poison mixed only with vegetable substances.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-18 ANIMAL LITTER OFF OWNER'S PREMISES.
   (a)   No owner of an animal shall cause or permit such animal to be on the
private property of any person other than such owner or on any public property
unless such owner has in his or her immediate possession an appropriate device
for the removal of such animal's excrement.
(Ord. No. 68-14-1464; Ord. No. 84-1-1687; Ord. No. 2001-19-3036)
   (b)   No owner of a dog shall permit such dog to deposit excrement on the
private property of any person other than such owner or on any public property
unless such owner shall immediately thereafter remove such excrement to a
proper receptacle located on such owner's property.
   (c)   This §
6-18 shall not apply to guide dogs for the handicapped.
(Ord. No. 84-1-1687; Ord. No. 2001-19-3036)
§ 6-19 RESERVED.
ARTICLE II. LICENSING OF ANIMALS
§ 6-20 LICENSING OF DOGS AND CATS.
   (a)   Any person owning, keeping, harboring or having custody of any dog or
cat over six months of age within this municipality must obtain a license as
herein provided.
   (b)   Written application for licenses shall be made to the village that
shall include all information required by the application form.
   (c)   If not revoked, licenses for the keeping of dogs and cats shall be for
a period of up to one year.
   (d)   Application for a license must be made within 30 days after obtaining
a dog or cat which is over six months, except that this requirement will not
apply to a non-resident keeping a dog or cat within the municipality for no
longer than 60 days.
   (e)   License fees shall not be required for guide dogs for the blind.
   (f)   (1)   Upon acceptance of the initial license application and fee, the
village shall issue a durable license tag stamped with an identifying number
and the year of issuance.
      (2)   The license tag is issued once for the life of the pet and annual
license renewal will occur without replacement of the tag.
      (3)   License tags shall be designed so that they may be conveniently
fastened to the animal’s collar or harness.
   (g)   Dogs and cats must wear license tags and collars at all times when off
the premises of the owners.
   (h)   The village shall maintain a record of the identifying numbers of all
license tags issued.
   (i)   The licensing period shall begin on May 1 and shall run for one year.
Application for annual licenses may be made 45 days prior to May 1 (by March 15
each year). Persons applying for a license during the licensing year shall be
required to pay the full fee stipulated in this section.
   (j)   The annual renewal application requires the payment of the applicable
fee set forth in the Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
   (k)   No more than four dogs and four cats may be licensed to be kept at any
family dwelling.
(Ord. No. 2014-19-3371; Ord. No. 2017-1-3409)
§ 6-21 LICENSING OF ACCESSORY ANIMALS.
   (a)   Accessory animal license application. Any person owning, keeping,
harboring or having custody of any accessory animal within the village must
obtain a license as herein provided. Only chickens may be kept as accessory
animals on property within the village. Keeping of any other accessory animal
is not permitted.
      (1)   Only the owner of a property used as a single-family dwelling may
apply for and receive an accessory animal license to keep chickens on their
property.
      (2)   A written application for an accessory animal license must be
submitted to the village and must include all information required by the
application form.
      (3)   Accessory animal licenses issued by the village shall be valid from
the date of issuance until the next succeeding January 1. Licenses must be
renewed annually.
      (4)   Maximum number of licenses: A maximum of ten accessory animal
licenses may be issued by the village at any time. Applications for accessory
animal licenses will be granted on a first come/first served basis. Renewals of
current accessory animal licenses will be given priority over new license
applicants.
      (5)   Application for an accessory animal license and each subsequent
renewal application must be accompanied by a payment of the applicable fee in
the amount set forth in the village's Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
      (6)   Licenses issued shall only benefit and inure to the applicant
listed on the application and will not run with property. A new license and
application fee shall be required in the event that an applicant or licensee
moves to a new address or transfers ownership of their accessory animals to a
person not already possessing an accessory animal license.
      (7)   At the time of issuance or renewal of an accessory animal license,
the village may impose specific conditions and restrictions upon the licensee
to prevent or minimize adverse effects on surrounding properties. Such
conditions or restrictions shall be expressly set forth in the license.
Violation of any such condition or restrictions shall be a violation of this
article and shall constitute grounds for revocation of the license.
      (8)   Any license issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the
director of public safety or their designee for a violation of any condition or
restrictions imposed upon a license, any provision of this chapter of the
village's code ordinances, or upon satisfactory proof that the licensed
activity was conducted in a manner detrimental to the public safety, health, or
welfare. Such revocation may be in addition to the imposition of any other
fines or penalties that may be applied pursuant to §
6-50 of this code of ordinances and shall be no defense to a prosecution for
such violation. A determination to revoke an accessory animal license by the
director of public safety or their designee shall be appealable to the village
manager no later than ten days after the issuance of the determination. The
appeal shall set forth with particularity the aspect or aspects of the
revocation determination from which the appeal is sought and the basis on which
the applicant believes the revocation determination was inconsistent with the
standards of this article. The village manager shall, after reviewing such
written appeal and making such investigations as the manager deems necessary or
appropriate, render a written decision on the appeal, which decision shall
either affirm, reverse or modify the determination of the director of public
safety or their designee. The decision of the village manager on the appeal
shall be final. Upon revocation of an accessory animal license, the accessory
animals and all enclosures, supplies and materials associated with the
accessory animals must be removed from the licensee's property no later than 14
days after the revocation is ordered.
   (b)   Inspections.
      (1)   Initial inspection. An inspection of the premises where accessory
animals are proposed to be kept shall be performed by the village prior to the
initial issuance of an accessory animal license, and periodically thereafter as
described herein. The applicant or licensee shall permit such inspection at
reasonable times and upon reasonable notice. Inspections shall be conducted
during regular business hours and only after reasonable advanced notice to the
applicant or licensee. An applicant's or licensee's consent to inspect their
property is an ongoing condition of any accessory animal license, and refusal
to permit an inspection shall be cause for rejection of an application or
revocation of an accessory animal license.
      (2)   Periodic inspections. The village may perform an inspection of
premises where accessory animals are kept for any of the following reasons:
         A.   The village requires an inspection as a condition of renewal of
an accessory animal license;
         B.   The applicant or licensee been issued a citation for violation of
any provision of this Code related to animal-keeping within the preceding 12
months; or
         C.   The village has probable cause to believe a violation of this
Code related to the licensed activity exists.
      (3)   Inspection criteria. The inspection shall verify that the applicant
or licensee provides adequate shelter, food, water, yard condition, yard
security, and other necessary conditions to preserve the health of the
accessory animals; and otherwise complies with the requirements of this
chapter. If any deficiency or deviation from the code of ordinance's conditions
and restrictions is found, the applicant or licensee must correct such
violation within such period of time as the village shall direct.
   (c)   Regulations for chickens. In addition to any other requirement of this
article, the following conditions and restriction shall apply to the keeping of
chickens authorized by an accessory animal license:
      (1)   No fewer than two adult chickens, and no more than four, adult
chickens may be kept or maintained on the property of a licensee at any one
time.
      (2)   Only female chickens (hens) may be kept or maintained on the
property of a licensee.
      (3)   A licensee shall not sell eggs produced by chickens upon the
property.
      (4)   No slaughtering of chickens may be conducted in public view on a
licensee's property.
      (5)   Enclosures for chickens:
         A.   Chickens must be kept in an enclosure, which may be in the form
of a pen, coop, or run.
         B.   Chicken enclosures will be considered accessory structures and
must satisfy all zoning requirements for accessory structures set forth in §
3-104 of the village's zoning code as well as all building permit requirements
for accessory structures set forth in Chapter 9 of the village code.
Notwithstanding any other applicable setback requirement for accessory
structures, chicken enclosures may be located no closer than ten feet from any
lot line of a property on which the enclosure is to be located.
         C.   Chicken enclosures may only be erected or maintained in the rear
of residential property, behind the principal structure on the licensee's lot.
Provided, however, that the village may, for good cause shown, allow enclosures
to be sited at an alternative location on a lot that provides a similar level
of visual screening, security, and privacy. No special notice or procedure is
required to grant this exception.
         D.   Chicken enclosures shall provide no less than four square feet of
area for each chicken housed.
         E.   Chicken enclosures must be maintained in a structurally sound and
useable condition.
         F.   Chicken enclosures must be constructed of sturdy and weather-
resistant materials, including without limitation, sturdy wire, wood, and
hardware cloth.
         G.   Chicken enclosures shall be secured to predators. All access
doors must be able to be shut and locked. All opening windows and vents must be
covered with predator-proof wire with less than one-inch openings.
      (6)   Chickens shall be provided with adequate open space on a licensee's
property in the form of either an enclosed chicken run or a yard fully enclosed
by a fence.
      (7)   Both a licensee's chicken enclosure and the accompanying open space
must be kept and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times.
      (8)   All feed as well as other supplies and materials associated with
the keeping of chickens must be stored or contained in a manner to prevent
rats, mice or other rodents from gaining access to or coming into contact with
the feed.
      (9)   No licensee shall permit:
         A.   Noxious or offensive odors from chicken-keeping, including the
odor of chickens or manure, to be perceptible at or beyond the boundary of the
licensee's property;
         B.   Offensive noise from chickens that disturbs the peace at any
time; or
         C.   Any other public or private nuisance resulting from the licensed
activity, consisting of litter, droppings, feathers, waste, or attraction of
pests or rodents.
      (10)   The licensee shall submit a livestock premises registration form
to the Illinois Department of Agriculture and shall provide a copy of the
submitted form to the village unless the Department shall stop accepting
residential chicken registrations.
(Ord. No. 2022-09-3529, § 2)
§§ 6-22 - 6-29 RESERVED.
ARTICLE III. IMPOUNDMENT OF ANIMALS
§ 6-30 IMPOUNDMENT.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of such village employees as shall be designated
for that purpose by the director of public safety to take up and impound any
animal found in the village in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter.
   (b)   Unless claimed by the owner, impounded animals shall be kept for not
less than five working days.
   (c)   If by a license tag or other means, the owner of an impounded animal
can be identified, the public safety department shall immediately upon
impoundment notify the owner by telephone or personal notification, if
practicable, and otherwise by mail.
   (d)   Any animal not claimed by its owner within five working days shall
become the property of the village, and shall be placed for adoption in a
suitable home or humanely destroyed as determined in the discretion of the
director of public safety.
   (e)   A complete registry of all impounded animals shall be kept indicating
breed, color and sex, and, if licensed, the name and address of the owner and
the license tag number.
   (f)   An owner or person claiming an impounded animal shall pay, before
release of such animal, an impounding fee as set forth in the Comprehensive Fee
and Fine Schedule, plus all costs of maintaining the animal while impounded and
any license fees required.
(Ord. No. 2014-19-3371)
§§ 6-31 - 6-39 RESERVED.
ARTICLE IV. RABIES CONTROL
§ 6-40 ANIMAL BITE NOTICE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person knowing that a person has been bitten by
an animal to fail to notify within 24 hours the director of public safety of
such fact.
(Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-41 DUTY TO KEEP ANIMAL FOR OBSERVATION.
   It shall be unlawful for the owner to sell, give away, destroy or otherwise
dispose of, or have inoculated against rabies an animal known to have bitten a
person until it has been released from confinement for observation for rabies
as provided herein.
(Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§ 6-42 PROCEDURE FOR OBSERVATION.
   (a)   The owner of an animal involved in a biting incident, upon receiving
notice of such fact in any manner, shall confine the biting animal under
observation of a licensed veterinarian for a period of ten days beginning
within 24 hours of the biting incident. The biting animal may be confined on
the premises of its owner in a manner that will prohibit it from biting any
person or animal if a licensed veterinarian adjudges such confinement
satisfactory.
      (1)   When the biting animal is currently inoculated with rabies vaccine
the animal's health shall be reported by the veterinarian to the director of
public safety on the first and tenth day of observation.
      (2)   When the biting animal is not currently inoculated with rabies
vaccine the animal's health shall be reported by the veterinarian to the
director of public safety on the first, fifth and tenth days of observation.
   (b)   If it is determined by the examining veterinarian that the confined
animal has rabies the director of public safety shall order the animal humanely
destroyed.
   (c)   If it is determined that the confined animal is not infected with
rabies then at the end of the period of confinement it shall be released to the
owner of such animal upon proof of a current rabies inoculation certificate and
license tag and upon payment of any fees and charges, including any fee for
veterinary services. If the animal is not claimed by the owner the animal may
be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of Ill. Rev. Stat. 1975, ch.
8, par. 361.
(Ord. 77-5-1547. § 1)
§ 6-43 ANIMALS AS PUBLIC NUISANCES.
   Any animal that shall bite, attack or attempt to bite one or more persons
three or more times within any five-year period is hereby declared to be a
public nuisance. The license for such animal shall be revoked by the director
of public safety and such animal shall not be kept within the village. If any
such animal shall be found within the village it shall be impounded and
disposed of as an unclaimed dog and the owner shall have no right to claim such
dog.
(Ord. No. 77-5-1547, § 1)
§§ 6-44 - 6-49 RESERVED.
ARTICLE V. PENALTIES
§ 6-50 PENALTIES.
   (a)   The owner of an animal violating §§
6-2(a),
6-2(b),
6-2(f),
6-2(g) or §
6-18 of this code in any licensing period shall be subject to a fine in the
amounts set forth in the Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
   (b)   Any violation of §§
6-2(c),
6-2(d),
6-2(e) or §
6-15 of this code shall require a court appearance and shall be subject to a
fine in the amounts set forth in the Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule, and
any other additional relief that the court finds necessary and appropriate,
including, but not limited to, ordering any dog to be muzzled, to be kept out
of the village or to be destroyed.
   (c)   The owner of an animal failing to provide required animal licensing
documentation as required under §
6-20 within 30 days of being notified of a deficiency in the application for a
pet license shall be subject to an additional administrative processing charge
in the amount set forth in the Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
   (d)   Any other violation of this chapter not specifically addressed in this
§
6-50 shall be subject to the provisions of §
16-1 of this code.
   (e)   Nothing in this section shall prohibit any person from seeking relief
in the civil courts against the owner of an animal committing a private
nuisance.
(Ord. No. 2014-19-3371)

Statutory reference:
   For state law as to authority of village to license and regulate

§ 7-1 AUCTIONEER'S LICENSE - REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct an auction in the village or do business as an
auctioneer without first having obtained a license therefor as hereinafter
provided in this chapter.
(1929 Code, § 393)
Cross-reference:
   As to licenses and permits generally, see
ch. 22
§ 7-2 SAME - APPLICATION.
   Application for auctioneers' licenses shall be made in writing to the
village manager. Such application shall state therein the place of business, if
any, intended to be occupied, and the names of any employees, not to exceed
two, who are desired to be authorized to conduct auctions under the authority
of the license.
(1929 Code, § 395)
§ 7-3 SAME - FEES.
   The fee, payable in advance, for auctioneers' licenses shall be $100 for an
annual license, $30 for a monthly license and $5 for a daily license.
(1929 Code, § 394)
§ 7-4 SAME - INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT.
   The chief of police, or any other officer designated by the village manager,
shall investigate the character of every applicant for an auctioneer's license.
(1929 Code, § 396)
§ 7-5 SAME - DENIAL TO PERSONS NOT OF GOOD MORAL CHARACTER.
   No auctioneer's license shall be issued under this chapter to any person who
is not of good moral character.
(1929 Code, § 396)
§ 7-6 SAME - ISSUANCE.
   Upon receipt of satisfactory proof of good moral character of an applicant
for an auctioneer's license, and upon receipt of the fee therefor required by §
7-3, the village manager shall cause the desired license to be issued.
§ 7-7 EMPLOYEES.
   Every person licensed as an auctioneer may designate employees, not to
exceed two in number, who may be authorized by him or her to conduct auctions.
Notice containing the names of the employees so designated shall be given to
the village manager, and an employee’s license shall be issued on the payment
of a fee as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
This license shall be valid for one year. It shall be unlawful for any employee
not licensed under this section to conduct an auction, or for an auctioneer to
permit an auction to be conducted by an unlicensed employee.
(1929 Code, § 397) (Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 7-8 AUCTIONS ON STREETS, ETC., PROHIBITED.
   No persons shall sell or attempt to sell or cry for sale at public auction
any goods, chattels or personal or real property of any kind upon the streets
or sidewalks of the village.
(1929 Code, § 398)
Cross-reference:
   As to streets and sidewalks generally, see
ch. 30
§ 7-9 CHAPTER NOT APPLICABLE ON CERTAIN SALES.
   Nothing in this chapter shall apply to any public auction or sale made or
conducted by a public officer by virtue of any judicial order or process or by
virtue of any power or authority contained in a mortgage or trust deed.
(1929 Code, § 399)

use

of razors, clippers, etc.
   
8-12   Cleaning and sterilization of articles that cannot be boiled

Cross-reference:
   As to health and sanitation generally, see
ch. 21
Statutory reference:
   As to authority of village to license, regulate, etc., barbers and
barbershops, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 24, § 11-42-1
   For state law as to barbers generally, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 16 3/4,
§§ 14.35 to 14.96
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
§ 8-1 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this chapter a BARBERSHOP means a fixed place of business
wherein barbering is practiced and carried on.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-2 PERMIT - REQUIRED.
   Every person in the village who desires to establish a barbershop or who
desires to continue and maintain a barbershop shall make application to the
health officer for a permit to do so.
(Ord. No. 1406)
Cross-reference:
   As to licenses and permits generally, see
ch. 22
§ 8-3 SAME - APPLICATION; INSPECTION OF PREMISES, ETC.; ISSUANCE.
   The application referred to in the preceding section shall be made in
writing and shall set forth the name of the proprietor or owner, the name of
the manager and the names of all persons who are employed in such barbershop,
together with the location, giving the street and number where such shop is to
be operated and maintained. If, upon inspection, it is found that such location
is suitable and that the persons to be employed are free from all communicable
diseases and that the sanitary regulations provided for in §§
8-7 to
8-22 can be strictly observed, then the health officer shall issue to such
person the permit applied for.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-4 LICENSE - REQUIRED.
   No person shall establish, maintain or operate any barbershop, as defined in
this chapter, without first having obtained a license to do so, in addition to
the permit from the health officer as provided for in §
8-2.
(Ord. No. 1406)
Cross-reference:
   As to licenses and permits generally, see
ch. 22
§ 8-5 SAME - APPLICATION, ETC.
   Every applicant for a license to operate a barbershop shall make application
for such license to the village clerk. At the time of making such application,
the applicant shall exhibit to the village clerk a valid state certificate of
registration as a registered barber and a permit from the health officer, as
required by §
8-2.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-6 SAME - FEE.
   The annual license fee for a barbershop shall be as set forth in the
village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
(Ord. No. 80-10-1610; Ord. No. 90-3-1812; Ord. No. 92-2-1868; Ord. No. 2016-04-
3394)
ARTICLE II. SANITARY REGULATIONS
§ 8-7 COMPLIANCE WITH ARTICLE.
   The owner or manager and all of the employees of any barbershop shall
conform strictly to the sanitary regulations set out in this article.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-8 VENTILATION, LIGHTING AND CONSTRUCTION OF PREMISES.
   Every barbershop shall be located in a building or room that is well
ventilated and well lighted and of such construction that it may be easily
cleaned.
(Ord. No. 1406)
Cross-reference:
   As to buildings and construction generally, see
ch. 9
§ 8-9 PREMISES, FIXTURES, INSTRUMENTS, ETC., TO BE KEPT CLEAN, SANITARY, ETC.
   All barbershops, together with the furniture, fixtures, instruments, and
linen therein, shall be kept in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition at all
times.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-10 HOT AND COLD RUNNING WATER REQUIRED; BOWLS, ETC., TO BE CLEANED AFTER
USE.
   All barbershops shall be at all times supplied with hot and cold running
water. All bowls, basins, jars and like receptacles shall be antiseptically
cleaned immediately after using.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-11 COMBS AND BRUSHES TO BE KEPT IN SANITARY CONDITION, ETC.; STERILIZATION
OF RAZORS, CLIPPERS, ETC.
   Combs and hair brushes shall be kept in a sanitary condition at all times
and shall be cleaned thoroughly with soap and hot water after each using. All
razors, shears, clippers and appliances shall be sterilized immediately after
being used by boiling water or steam sterilization or by proper use of approved
liquid germicides. Thereafter, until used, such instruments and appliances
shall be kept in a sterilized cabinet full of the fumes of formaldehyde gas
solution, changed daily.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-12 CLEANING AND STERILIZATION OF ARTICLES THAT CANNOT BE BOILED.
   Glass or metal articles that cannot be boiled shall be cleaned in soap and
water, wiped in alcohol and kept in a formaldehyde sterilizer, or immersed in
an approved germicidal solution for not less than one hour.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-13 TOWELS, LINEN, ETC.
   Only unused, freshly laundered towels, including dry towels, steamed towels
or wash cloths, shall be used for each patron. All clean linen shall be kept in
a closed cabinet until used. The headrest shall be covered with a freshly
laundered towel or fresh paper before using for each patron. In cutting the
hair of any person, a freshly laundered towel or fresh paper neck strip shall
be placed about the neck so as to prevent the hair cloth from touching the
skin.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-14 USE OF STYPTIC, ALUM, ETC.
   The use of lump alum, styptic pencils, finger bowls, shaving mugs, powder
puffs and sponges is prohibited. The use of styptic, alum in powder or liquid
form and individual applicators is permitted.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-15 BARBER WITH CONTAGIOUS, ETC., DISEASE PROHIBITED.
   No barber having a contagious or infectious disease shall be permitted to
work in a barbershop.
(Ord. No. 1406)
Charter reference:
   For charter provision as to authority of village with regard to prevention
of contagious diseases, etc., see char.,
art. IV, § 5
§ 8-16 SLEEPING IN BARBERSHOP.
   No barbershop shall be used as a place in which to sleep.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-17 STERILIZATION OF INSTRUMENTS, ETC., AFTER USE UPON SICK PERSON.
   All tools, instruments or appliances shall be thoroughly sterilized
immediately after their use upon any sick person.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-18 PERSONAL CLEANLINESS OF BARBERS.
   Every barber or other employee shall wash his or her hands thoroughly
immediately before and after serving each customer and shall, while serving
customers, wear a clean, washable apron or coat.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-19 STATE SANITARY RULES TO BE ENFORCED.
   The sanitary rules for barbershops of the State Department of Registration,
or any other agency of the state authorized to promulgate such rules, that are
now and from time to time in the future enforced, shall be given the same force
and effect as if they were set forth in this article insofar as they are not
inconsistent with the requirements of this article, and violations thereof
shall be subject to the same penalties provided for the violations of the other
regulations of this article.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-20 REGULATIONS TO BE POSTED.
   A copy of the regulations set out in this article shall be posted in a
conspicuous place in each barbershop for the information and guidance of
persons working or employed therein and for the public at large.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-21 BARBER'S CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION TO BE DISPLAYED.
   It shall be the duty of every barber to conspicuously display his or her
certificate of registration at all times in front of his or her work stand or
mirror where it may readily be seen by all persons whom he or she serves.
(Ord. No. 1406)
§ 8-22 VIOLATION OF ARTICLE.
   Any person violating any of the regulations set out in this article shall,
upon conviction, be punished as provided in §
16-1.
(Ord. No. 1406)
