ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
§ 23-1 DEFINITIONS.
   The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall, for the
purpose of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in
this section, except when the context otherwise requires.
   BUSINESS DISTRICT. The territory contiguous to and including a highway, when
within any 600 feet along such highway there are buildings in use for business
or industrial purposes, including, but not limited to, hotels, banks or office
buildings, railroad stations and public buildings which occupy at least 300
feet of frontage on one side or 300 feet collectively on both sides of the
highway.
   COMMERCIAL VEHICLE. Every vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for
the transportation of property.
   CROSSWALK.
      (1)   The part of a roadway at an intersection included within the
connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the
highway measured from the curbs, or in the absence of curbs from the edges of
the traversable roadway.
      (2)   Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly
indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface.
   DRIVER. Every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a
vehicle.
   INTERSECTION.
      (1)   The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the
lateral curb lines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the
roadways, of two highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right
angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways
joining at any other angle may come in conflict.
      (2)   Where a highway includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then
every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting
highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection.
   LANED ROADWAY. A roadway that is divided into two or more clearly marked
lanes for vehicular traffic.
   MOTOR VEHICLE. Every vehicle that is self-propelled, except for (i) vehicles
moved solely by human power, and (ii) motor-driven vehicles, as defined in
Section
23-120  of this code.
   MOTORCYCLE. Every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the
rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the
ground, but excluding a tractor.
   OFFICIAL TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES. All signs, signals, markings and devices
not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by authority of a public
body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or
guiding traffic.
   PARK or PARKING. The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not,
otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in
loading or unloading merchandise or passengers.
   PARKWAY. The portion of a street between the edge of the improved roadway
and the adjacent property line.
   PEDESTRIAN. Any person afoot.
   PRIVATE ROAD OR DRIVEWAY. Every way or place in private ownership and used
for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied
permission from the owner, but not by other persons.
   RESIDENCE DISTRICT. The territory contiguous to and including a highway not
comprising a business district when the property on such highway for a distance
of 300 feet or more is in the main improved with residences or residences and
buildings in use for business.
   RIGHT-OF-WAY. The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway.
   ROADWAY. The portion of a highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for
vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. In the event a highway
includes two or more separate roadways, the term ROADWAY as used herein shall
refer to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways
collectively.
   SAFETY ZONE. The area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the
exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or
indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set
apart as a safety zone.
   SCHOOL BUS. Every motor vehicle owned by a public or governmental agency and
operated for the transportation of children to or from school or privately
owned and operated for compensation for the transportation of children to or
from school.
   SCHOOL CROSSING SIGNALS. A permanently mounted electrically operated signal
device equipped with two-way, two color (red and yellow) signal heads, together
with a diamond shaped, signal faced sign reading "school crossing," by which at
predetermined times and when actuated by push button, traffic is directed to
stop so as to permit school children to cross the street or highway safely.
   SIDEWALK. The portion of a street between the curb lines or the lateral
lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines, intended for use of
pedestrians.
   STAND or STANDING. The halting of a vehicle, whether occupied or not,
otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in
receiving or discharging passengers.
   STOP. When required, means complete cessation of movement.
   STOP or STOPPING. When prohibited, is any halting, even momentarily, of a
vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with
other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or
traffic-control sign or signal.
   STREET or HIGHWAY. The entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for
purposes of vehicular travel.
   STREET END. The extension along public property of the following streets
lying east of Sheridan Road from the end of the paved area used for purposes of
vehicular traffic eastward to, but not including, the beach: Beach Road, Dell
Place, Harbor Street, Hazel Avenue, Maple Hill Road, Park Avenue and South
Avenue.
   THROUGH HIGHWAY. Every highway or portion thereof on which vehicular traffic
is given preferential right-of-way, and at the entrances to which vehicular
traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to yield the right-of-way
to vehicles on such through highway in obedience to either a stop sign or a
yield sign, when such signs are erected as provided in this chapter.
   TRAFFIC. Pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other
conveyances either singly or together while using any highway for purposes of
travel.
   TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNAL. Any device, whether manually, electrically or
mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to
proceed.
   URBAN DISTRICT. The territory contiguous to and including any street which
is built up with structures devoted to business, industry or dwelling houses
situated at intervals of less than 100 feet for a distance of a quarter of a
mile or more.
   VEHICLE. Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may
be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or
used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks.
(Ord. No. 82-12-1698)
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law definitions, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, §§ 1-
101 to 1-190 and 99 to 116a
§ 23-2 OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC REGULATIONS; ADOPTION OF ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful and, unless otherwise declared in this chapter
with respect to particular offenses, it is a misdemeanor for any person to do
any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this chapter,
including those actions forbidden or required by the Illinois Vehicle Code,
which is adopted by reference in §
23-2(b) below.
   (b)   The Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq., as amended from
time to time, is hereby adopted by reference to be applied within the corporate
limits of the village to the extent permitted by law.
(Ord. 2017-16-3424; Ord. 2024-14-3591)
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 118
§ 23-3 POLICE TO DIRECT TRAFFIC; DIRECTING IN EVENT OF FIRE OR EMERGENCY.
   (a)   Officers of the police department or such other persons as are
assigned by the chief of police are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by
voice, hand or signal in conformance with the provisions of this chapter;
provided, that in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic
or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct
traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of this
chapter.
   (b)   Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may
direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate
vicinity.
§ 23-4 OBEDIENCE TO POLICE.
   No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or
direction of any police officer or other person invested by law with authority
to direct, control or regulate traffic.
Cross-reference:
   As to police department generally, see §§
2-84 to
2-87
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat., ch. 95 ½, § 11-203
§ 23-5 PERSONS PROPELLING PUSHCARTS OR RIDING OR DRIVING ANIMALS SUBJECT TO
TRAFFIC REGULATIONS.
   Every person propelling a pushcart or riding an animal or driving any animal
drawing a vehicle upon a roadway shall be subject to the provisions of this
chapter applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except those provisions of this
chapter which by their nature can have no application.
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to applicability of traffic laws to person riding animals,
etc., see Ill. Rev. Stat., ch. 95 ½, § 11-206
§ 23-6 PERMITS FOR PARADES AND PROCESSIONS.
   No parade containing more than ten persons shall occupy, march or proceed
along any street except pursuant to a permit issued by the village manager and
such regulations as are set forth in this chapter which may apply. The
applicant for such a permit shall apply for a permit 14 days preceding the
parade. The village manager shall designate the parade route.
(Ord. No. 78-15-1571, § 1)
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to authority of village to regulate, etc., processions, see
Ill. Rev. Stat., § 11-208
§ 23-7 FUNERAL PROCESSION TO BE IDENTIFIED.
   A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such
by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant or other
identifying insignia or by such other method as may be determined and
designated by the village manager.
Cross-reference:
   As to driving through processions, see §
23-79
§ 23-8 CERTAIN VEHICLES PROHIBITED ON SHERIDAN ROAD; PROVISO.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any freight carrying vehicle,
stream roller or traction engine on Sheridan Road, except to cross it in case
of necessity at intersections; provided, however, that deliveries may be made
to premises on Sheridan Road, and for the purpose of making such deliveries
freight carrying vehicles may be permitted to travel on Sheridan Road for not
to exceed one block.
§ 23-9 CLINGING TO MOVING VEHICLES.
   No person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates
or any toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself or herself to any moving
vehicle upon any roadway.
§ 23-10 BOARDING OR ALIGHTING FROM MOVING VEHICLES.
   No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in
motion.
§ 23-11 UNLAWFUL RIDING GENERALLY.
   No person shall ride on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or
intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to an
employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding
within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise.
§ 23-12 USE OF COASTERS, ROLLER SKATES, ETC., RESTRICTED.
   No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy
vehicle or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a
street on a crosswalk, and when so crossing such person shall be granted all of
the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians.
This section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play street
as authorized by this code or other ordinance of the village.
Cross-reference:
   As to playing games on streets, see §
30-9
§ 23-13 AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLES GENERALLY.
   (a)   The provisions of this chapter regulating the movement or parking of
vehicles shall not apply to the driver of any authorized emergency vehicle when
responding to an emergency call, but such driver on approaching a red or stop
signal or any stop sign shall slow down as necessary for safety but may proceed
cautiously past such red or stop sign or signal. At other times drivers of
authorized emergency vehicles shall stop in obedience to a stop sign or signal.
   (b)   No driver of any authorized emergency vehicle shall assume any special
privileges under this section except when such vehicle is operated in response
to an emergency call or in the immediate pursuit of an actual or suspected
violator of the law.
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 120
§ 23-14 DUTY OF OPERATOR IN EVENT OF ACCIDENT.
   It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle which has collided with
any person or property in such a manner as to cause an injury or damage to any
person or property to fail or refuse to stop immediately to ascertain the
extent of such injury or damage, to render such assistance as may be needed, to
give his or her true name and residence to the injured person or any other
persons requesting the same, and to give notice of such accident to a police
officer, or if no police officer is present, then to the village police
department.
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to accidents generally, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½,
§§ 133 to 143
ARTICLE II. BICYCLES
§ 23-15 SUBJECT TO TRAFFIC REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Bicycles are hereby classed as vehicles and every person operating a
bicycle shall be subject to the provisions of all state vehicle laws and all
traffic provisions of this code and other ordinances of the village, except
such provisions in conflict with this article or which by their nature can have
no application.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a bicycle to fail or
refuse to comply with any order, signal or direction of a police officer, or to
disobey the instructions or any official traffic sign, signal or other traffic-
control device.
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to applicability of traffic laws to bicycle riders, see
Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 121
§ 23-16 LIGHTS REQUIRED.
   (a)   Every bicycle, when upon a street or highway within the village during
the period from sunset to sunrise, shall be equipped with at least one lighted
lamp exhibiting a white light, or light of a yellow or amber tint, visible from
a distance of 500 feet to the front of the bicycle and with at least one
lighted lamp exhibiting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the
rear thereof.
   (b)   Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be guilty
of a misdemeanor.
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 204a
§ 23-17 AUDIBLE WARNING DEVICES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a bicycle on any street,
sidewalk or other public place which is not equipped with a warning device, in
good working order and audible at a distance of not less than 25 feet when
sounded; except, that no bicycle may be equipped with or make use of any gong,
siren or mechanical whistle.
Statutory reference:
   For state law prohibiting sirens or whistles or bicycles, see Ill. Rev.
Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 212(c)
§ 23-18 BRAKES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a bicycle on any street,
sidewalk or other public place without a brake that will enable the operator to
make the brake wheel skid on a dry, level, clean pavement.
§ 23-19 RIDING ON SIDEWALKS.
   Bicycles may be operated on sidewalks except where such operation is
prohibited under §
23-28. Pedestrians on sidewalks shall be given the right-of-way at all times,
and the operator of a bicycle shall give an audible signal before overtaking or
passing any pedestrian.
§ 23-20 SPEED.
   No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and
prudent under the conditions then existing, taking into account the safety of
the rider and of other persons, property and vehicles.
§ 23-21 STOPPING AND TURNING.
   No operator of a bicycle shall suddenly stop, slow down or turn without
giving an arm signal as provided by state law for the operation of motor
vehicles.
§ 23-22 RIDING ON RIGHT.
   Every person operating a bicycle shall keep to the right and shall operate
as nearly as practicable at the right-hand edge of the roadway or sidewalk.
§ 23-23 RIDING IN A GROUP.
   When two or more persons are operating bicycles in a group, they shall ride
single file and it shall be unlawful for them to ride abreast of each other.
§ 23-24 EMERGING FROM ALLEYS, DRIVEWAYS OR BUILDINGS.
   The operator of a bicycle coming out of an alley, driveway or building shall
stop before riding on or across a sidewalk or into a roadway if the view is
obscured. Such operator shall in all cases yield the right-of-way to all
pedestrians approaching on such sidewalk, and to all vehicles approaching on
such roadway.
§ 23-25 EXTRA PASSENGERS.
   No bicycles shall be used to carry more than one person at any time unless
it is a tandem or multiple bicycle and so designed and equipped.
§ 23-26 CARRYING ARTICLES.
   No person operating a bicycle shall carry a package, bundle or article which
prevents him or her from keeping both hands on the handlebars, or from
operating the bicycle in a proper and efficient manner.
§ 23-27 TRICK, ETC., RIDING.
   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a bicycle on the public
streets to indulge in any kind of trick or unsafe riding.
§ 23-28 RIDING AT CERTAIN LOCATIONS MAY BE PROHIBITED.
   The village manager is hereby authorized to erect signs on any street,
sidewalk or other public place prohibiting the riding of bicycles thereon. When
such signs are in place, it shall be unlawful to ride a bicycle on such street,
sidewalk or other public place.
§ 23-29 PARKING.
   No bicycle shall be operated or parked on any street, sidewalk or other
public place in such a manner as to unreasonably block or interfere with
pedestrian or vehicular traffic. The village manager is hereby authorized to
designate certain areas in any congested district where bicycles may be parked.
When such areas have been so designated, it shall be unlawful to park bicycles
in such congested district except in such areas.
Cross-reference:
   As to stopping, standing and parking generally, see §§
23-84 to
23-93.3
§ 23-30 RESPONSIBILITY OF PARENTS, ETC., OF CYCLISTS.
   It shall be unlawful for the parent of any child or the guardian of any ward
to authorize or knowingly permit any child or ward to violate any of the
provisions of this article.
§ 23-31 IMPOUNDING.
   In addition to or in lieu of the penalties provided by this code, any person
who commits a violation of this article may be punished by the impounding of
the bicycle used in committing any such violation for a period not exceeding 30
days. Such impounding shall be at the discretion of the chief of police.
§ 23-32 REGISTRATION - GENERALLY.
   The village encourages the registration of bicycles intended to be operated
or otherwise used within the village.
(Ord. No. 09-20-3253)
Cross-reference:
   As to village vehicle licenses, see §§
23-65 to
23-70
§ 23-33 SAME - SAME - RENTAL AGENCIES.
   All persons engaged in operating bicycle rental agencies for the purpose of
renting or lending bicycles to patrons shall first obtain registration
certificates and plates for such bicycles. Registration certificates and plates
thus obtained by bicycle rental agencies shall not be transferred from one
bicycle to another.
§ 23-34 SAME - RECIPROCITY WITH OTHER MUNICIPALITIES.
   Any non-resident of the village may operate in the village any bicycle which
is duly registered in another municipality and equipped with a registration
plate, without obtaining a village registration plate; provided, that such
other municipality wherein such bicycle is licensed or registered extends the
same privilege to the residents of the village.
§ 23-35 SAME - APPLICATION; MECHANICAL CONDITION OF BICYCLE.
   Every person desiring a bicycle registration plate to be issued by the
village shall make application to the police department upon blanks furnished
by the village. Such application shall contain such information as may be
required by the chief of police concerning the applicant and the description of
the bicycle to be registered. No registration plate shall be issued unless the
bicycle complies with the requirements of this article concerning its safe
mechanical condition.
§ 23-36 SAME - FEE.
   No fee shall be required for the initial registration of the bicycle. Upon
loss of the registration the registree shall report as lost within seven days;
upon receipt of such report the police shall cancel the original registration
and issue a new registration plate to the registree.
(Ord. No. 92-2-1868)
§ 23-37 SAME - EXAMINATION; WHEN REGISTRATION MAY BE DENIED.
   Upon making an application for the initial registration of a bicycle, the
applicant shall be examined by an examining officer designated by the chief of
police. The chief of police shall designate the scope and manner of the
examination. Upon completion of such examination, the chief of police may
refuse to issue a registration plate to the applicant if such examination
discloses to the chief of police that the applicant does not have a reasonable
knowledge of the provisions of this article or that the applicant is unable to
exercise reasonable control in operating a bicycle.
§ 23-38 SAME - ISSUANCE; DURATION.
   Upon approval of the application referred to in §
23-35, the chief of police shall issue a registration plate which shall be
effective as long as the bicycle remains under the ownership of the applicant.
§ 23-39 SAME - TRANSFERABILITY; WHEN DEEMED CANCELLED.
   No registration plate shall be transferred from one bicycle to another or
from one owner to another. A registration plate shall be deemed to be cancelled
when the bicycle is sold, exchanged, junked or is disposed of in any other
manner by the person to whom the registration plate was originally issued.
§ 23-40 SALES TO BE REPORTED AND TAGS OF SOLD BICYCLES RETURNED.
   Every person, other than the operator of a bicycle establishment, who sells
or transfers ownership of any bicycle shall report the sale or transfer of
ownership to the chief of police. He or she shall return the registration plate
issued to such person to the chief of police, together with the name and
address of the person to whom such bicycle has been sold or transferred, within
seven days from the date of sale or transfer. If the sale or transfer is made
to the operator of a bicycle establishment, then such registration plate shall
be given to the owner of such bicycle establishment who shall then forward the
registration plate to the chief of police.
§ 23-41 JUNKING BICYCLES.
   Upon dismantling and disposing of any bicycle as junk, the registree shall
turn in his or her registration plate to the chief of police.
§ 23-42 REMOVAL, ETC., OF SERIAL NUMBERS AND PLATES - GENERALLY.
   No person shall willfully remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the
manufacturer's serial number or the village serial number, if any, on any
bicycle frame, nor shall any person remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any
registration plate during the period for which such registration plate is in
effect.
Cross-reference:
   As to public garages changing auto plates and engine numbers, see §
15-17
§ 23-43 SAME - DEALING, ETC., IN BICYCLES FROM WHICH DISTINGUISHING MARKS
REMOVED, ETC.
   No person shall buy, sell receive, dispose of or conceal any bicycle or
bicycle equipment from which the manufacturer's name plate, serial number or
any other distinguishing mark has been removed, defaced, covered, altered or
destroyed.
§ 23-44 POLICE DEPARTMENT SERIAL NUMBER.
   If the serial number of any bicycle is obliterated or defaced, and the
possessor has satisfactory proof of ownership, the chief of police is hereby
authorized to place a police department serial number thereon.
§ 23-45 POLICE AUCTION.
   All abandoned bicycles and unidentified bicycles remaining in the hands of
the chief of police shall be sold at auction after six months.
Cross-reference:
   As to auctions and auctioneers generally, see
ch. 7
§ 23-45.1 PROTECTIVE HELMETS.
   (a)   Helmet required. Every person under the age of 16 years, whenever
riding or being carried on or upon any bicycle, carrier attached to or pulled
by a bicycle, skateboard, roller or inline skates, or non-motorized scooter on
a public street, sidewalk, bicycle path or other public right-of-way in the
village, shall wear a protective helmet that meets the standards promulgated by
the American National Standards Institute, the American Society for Testing and
Materials or the Snell Memorial Foundation.
   (b)   Violation; penalties. Every person who is found to have violated the
provisions of this section shall be subject to the following penalties.
      (1)   First violation. A notice shall be sent to the parents or legal
guardians of the violator regarding the violation.
      (2)   Second violation. The violator shall either:
         A.   Be required to attend an educational program provided by the
department of public safety on public safety-related subjects including the use
of protective helmets; or
         B.   If the violator fails to attend the educational program as
provided in subsection
23-45.1(b)(2)A. of this section, be subject to a fine as set forth in the
village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
      (3)   Third violation. The violator shall either:
         A.   Be required to complete, to the satisfaction of the department of
public safety, ten hours of community service in the village within a time
period to be prescribed by the department of public safety; or
         B.   If the violator fails to provide the community service as
directed by the department of public safety and within the time period
prescribed therefor as provided in subsection
23-45.1(b)(2)A. of this section, be subject to a fine as set forth in the
village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
      (4)   Fourth and subsequent violations. The violator shall either:
         A.   Be required to complete, to the satisfaction of the department of
public safety, 20 hours of community service in the village within a time
period to be prescribed by the department of public safety; or
         B.   If the violator fails to provide the community service as
directed within the time period prescribed, shall be subject to a fine as set
forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule.
(Ord. No. 06-22-3164; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
ARTICLE III. PEDESTRIANS
§ 23-46 PEDESTRIANS' RIGHT-OF-WAY AT CROSSWALKS.
   (a)   Where traffic-control signals are not in operation, the driver of a
vehicle shall yield the right-of- way, slowing down or stopping if need be, to
a pedestrian crossing the roadway or street within any marked or unmarked
crosswalk.
   (b)   Wherever stop signals or flashing red signals are in place at an
intersection or a marked crosswalk between intersections, the pedestrian shall
have the right-of-way over drivers of vehicles; and at such marked places
drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk and any
pedestrian within or entering the crosswalk at either edge of the roadway shall
have the right-of-way over any vehicle so stopped.
   (c)   The driver of a vehicle shall stop before entering any crosswalk, when
any vehicle proceeding in the same direction is stopped at such crosswalk for
the purpose of permitting a pedestrian to cross.
§ 23-47 CROSSING AT OTHER THAN CROSSWALKS; LOITERING, ETC., IN ROADWAY.
   (a)   At no place shall a pedestrian cross any roadway other than by the
most direct route to the opposite curbing, and when crossing at any place other
than a crosswalk, he or she shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon
the roadway.
   (b)   No person shall stand or loiter in any roadway other than in a safety
zone, if such act interferes with the lawful movement of traffic.
Cross-reference:
   As to loitering, etc., in fire engine rooms, etc., see §
24-36
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to crossing at other than crosswalks, see Ill. Rev. Stat.
1963, ch. 95 ½, § 172
§ 23-48 PEDESTRIANS TO OBEY SIGNALS.
   At intersections where traffic is directed by a police officer or by a stop
and go signal, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to cross the roadway
other than with released traffic, if such crossing interferes with the lawful
movement of traffic.
§ 23-49 PEDESTRIANS NOT TO OBSTRUCT SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to stand upon any sidewalk except as
near as reasonably possible to the building line or curb line, if such standing
interferes with the use of the sidewalk by other pedestrians.
Cross-reference:
   As to streets and sidewalks generally, see
ch. 30
§ 23-50 CROSSING ROADWAY GENERALLY.
   (a)   Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in
operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk.
   (b)   No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any
business section.
§ 23-51 WALKING ALONG ROADWAYS.
   (a)   Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian
to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway.
   (b)   Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and
upon a highway shall when practicable walk only on the left side of the roadway
or its shoulder facing traffic, and upon meeting a vehicle shall step off to
the left.
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to pedestrians walking on highways, see Ill. Rev. Stat.
1963, ch. 95 ½, § 175
§ 23-51.1 ENTRY UPON STREET ENDS.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian or any other person at any time
to enter upon the street ends or the beaches under the control of the village
adjoining the street ends at Beach Road, Harbor Street, Hazel Avenue and Park
Avenue; provided, however, that this prohibition shall not apply to paved paths
crossing street ends and leading to beaches not under such control. The village
manager shall cause to be placed appropriate signs or devices at such street
ends indicating the same.
(Ord. No. 84-12-1698)
   (b)   Between 7:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., it shall be unlawful for a pedestrian
or other person to enter upon the street ends, or the beaches under the control
of the village adjoining the street ends, at Dell Place, Maple Hill Road and
South Avenue. The village manager shall cause to be placed appropriate signs or
devices at such street ends indicating the same.
§ 23-52 SOLICITING RIDES.
   No person shall stand in any portion of the public street between the
property lines thereof for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of
any private vehicle.
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 174
§ 23-53 RIGHT-OF-WAY OF BLIND PERSONS.
   (a)   Any blind person who is carrying in a raised or extended position a
cane or walking stick which is white in color or white tipped with red, or who
is guided by a dog, shall have the right-of-way in crossing any street or
highway, whether or not traffic on such street or highway is controlled by
traffic signals, anything in this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding.
   (b)   The driver of every vehicle approaching the place where a blind
person, so carrying such a cane or walking stick or being guided, is crossing a
street or highway, shall bring his or her vehicle to a full stop and before
proceeding shall take such precautions as may be necessary to avoid injury to
the blind person.
   (c)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to a blind person who
is not carrying such a cane or walking stick or guided by a guide dog when
walking on streets, highways or sidewalks but such fact shall not be considered
evidence of contributory negligence.
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch 95 ½, § 172a
ARTICLE IV. TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES
§ 23-54 AUTHORITY TO INSTALL GENERALLY.
   The village manager shall cause to be placed and maintained traffic-control
signs, signals and other devices when and as required under this chapter and
under state laws to make effective the provisions of this chapter and such
state laws to make effective the provisions of this chapter and such state laws
and may cause to be placed and maintained such additional traffic-control
devices as he or she may deem necessary to regulate traffic under the
provisions of this chapter or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic.
§ 23-55 OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES.
   No driver of a vehicle shall disobey the instructions of any official
traffic-control device placed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter
unless at the time otherwise directed by a police officer.
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to obedience to traffic-control devices, see Ill. Rev.
Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 128
§ 23-56 TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNAL LEGEND - GENERALLY.
   Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals exhibiting
different colored lights successively one at a time, or with arrows, only the
following colors shall be used and such terms and lights shall indicate and
apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians, as follows.
   (a)   Circular green (alone).
      (1)   Vehicle traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through or
turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn. But
vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to
pedestrians lawfully within the intersection at the time such signal is
exhibited.
      (2)   Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within
any marked or unmarked crosswalk unless directed otherwise by a pedestrian
signal.
   (b)   Steady yellow.
      (1)   Vehicular traffic facing the signal is thereby warned that the red
indication will be exhibited immediately thereafter of the related green
movement is being terminated, and shall stop before entering the nearest
crosswalk at the intersection, but if such stop cannot be made in safety, a
vehicle may be driven cautiously through the intersection.
      (2)   Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian signal, pedestrians
facing such signal are thereby advised that there is insufficient time to cross
the roadway, and any pedestrian then starting to cross shall yield the right-
of-way to all vehicles.
   (c)   Steady red (alone).
      (1)   Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering the
nearest crosswalk at an intersection or at such other point as may be indicated
by a clearly visible line or if none, before entering the intersection, and
shall remain standing until the green indication is shown unless otherwise
directed by a sign or arrow.
      (2)   No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway unless he
or she can do so safely and without interfering with any vehicular traffic or
unless a separate "Walk" indication is shown.
   (d)   Green straight-through arrow (alone).
      (1)   Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through,
but shall not turn right or left. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right-
of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians legally within the intersection at
the time such signal is exhibited.
      (2)   Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within
the appropriate marked or unmarked crosswalk unless directed otherwise by a
pedestrian signal.
   (e)   Green turn arrow (alone or with circular green, with steady yellow,
with steady red or with green straight-through arrow).
      (1)   Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall comply with the meaning
of the circular green, steady yellow, steady red or green straight-through
arrow indication as if it where shown alone; except, that such vehicular
traffic may cautiously enter the intersection to make the movement indicated by
the green turn arrow. Vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to
pedestrians lawfully within a crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the
intersection.
      (2)   Pedestrians facing such signal shall comply with the meaning of the
circular green, steady yellow, steady red or straight-through arrow indication
as if were shown alone, unless directed otherwise by a pedestrian signal.
   (f)   Signal at a place other than an intersection. In the event an official
traffic-control signal or flashing red signal is erected and maintained at a
place other than an intersection, the provisions of this section or §
23-58 shall be applicable except as to provisions which by their nature can
have no application. Any stop required shall be at a sign or marking on the
pavement indicating where the stop shall be made, but in the absence of any
such sign or marking the stop shall be made at the signal.
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 129
§ 23-57 SAME - PEDESTRIAN CONTROL SIGNALS.
   Whenever special pedestrian control signals exhibiting the words "Walk" or
"Don't Walk" are in place, such signals shall indicate as follows.
   (a)   Walk. While the "Walk" indication is illuminated, pedestrians facing
such signal may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal, and
shall be given the right-of-way by the drivers of all vehicles.
   (b)   Don't walk. While the "Don't Walk" indication is illuminated, either
steady or flashing, no pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the
direction of the signal, but any pedestrian who has partly completed his or her
crossing during the "Walk" indication shall proceed to a sidewalk, or to a
safety island if one is provided.
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 129a
§ 23-58 SAME - FLASHING SIGNALS.
   Whenever flashing red or yellow signals are used, they shall require
obedience by vehicular traffic as follows.
   (a)   Flashing red (stop signal). When a red lens is illuminated by rapid
intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the
nearest crosswalk at an intersection or at a limit line when marked or, if
none, then before entering the intersection and the right to proceed shall be
subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign.
   (b)   Flashing yellow (caution signal). When a yellow lens is illuminated
with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the
intersection or past such signal only with caution.
§ 23-59 AUTHORITY OF VILLAGE MANAGER - TO ESTABLISH CROSSWALKS, TRAFFIC PARKING
LANES, LOADING ZONES, ETC.
   The village manager is hereby authorized to establish, designate and set off
with appropriate markings, signs or other devices, crosswalks, traffic lanes,
parking lanes and spaces, bus stops, taxicab stands, passenger zones and
loading zones, and other places established, designated or set off for the
enforcement of this chapter, and the village manager shall determine the
character and kind of such markings, signs or other devices.
Cross-reference:
   As to village manager generally, see §§
2-20 to
2-27
§ 23-60 SAME - TO DESIGNATE ONE-WAY STREETS AND RESTRICT TURNING AT
INTERSECTIONS.
   (a)   Subject to approval of the board of trustees, the village manager is
hereby empowered to designate certain streets or alleys or portions thereof
along which vehicles shall travel only in one prescribed direction, and to
designate certain intersections at which vehicles shall not make left-hand or
right-hand or U-turns, as the case may be.
   (B)   The village manager shall cause the placement of proper signs along
such streets, alleys and at such intersections indicating the direction of
travel and the kinds of turns which are prohibited.
§ 23-61 SAME - TO DESIGNATE THROUGH STREETS AND STOP, ETC., INTERSECTIONS.
   (a)   Subject to approval of the board of trustees, the village manager may
designate certain streets or portions thereof as through streets and shall
cause to be erected and maintained an appropriate stop sign on each
intersecting such through streets.
   (b)   The village manager may designate street intersections in addition to
the intersections of through streets as dangerous or hazardous intersections
and shall cause a stop sign or "yield right-of-way" sign to be erected and
maintained at each such dangerous or hazardous intersection.
§ 23-62 SAME - TO ESTABLISH PLAY STREETS AND ZONES OF QUIET.
   (a)   The village manager shall have authority to declare any street or part
thereof a play street and shall cause to be placed appropriate signs or devices
in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same.
   (b)   The village manager shall also have authority to establish zones of
quiet in streets adjacent to hospitals or elsewhere whenever in his or her
judgment such quiet zones are necessary for the welfare of inmates of such
hospitals or others and shall cause to be placed appropriate signs designating
such zones as zones of quiet.
§ 23-63 DISPLAY OF UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS, SIGNALS OR MARKINGS, ETC.
   No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway
any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is an
imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or railroad sign
or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, nor shall any
person place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway any other sign
which hides from view or interferes with the movement of traffic or the
effectiveness of any traffic-control device or any railroad sign or signal, and
no person shall place or maintain upon any highway any traffic sign or signal
bearing thereon any commercial advertising, and the village manager may remove
or cause to be removed any sign or signal.
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 1/2, § 131
§ 23-64 INTERFERENCE WITH OFFICIAL TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES OR RAILROAD SIGNS OR
SIGNALS.
   No person shall without lawful authority attempt to or in fact alter,
deface, injure, knock down or remove any official traffic-control device, or
any railroad sign or signal or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon, or
any other part thereof.
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 132
ARTICLE V. VILLAGE LICENSES
§ 23-65 REQUIRED.
   Any motor vehicle registered with the State of Illinois (or any other state)
to an address within the corporate limits of the village by a person, residing
or maintaining a place of business within the village, is required to be a
licensed as provided in this article.
(Ord. No. 2014-19-3371)
§ 23-66 APPLICATION.
   Any person desiring a license for any motor vehicle shall file an
application with the village, upon such forms as the village shall prescribe.
New residents moving into the corporate limits of the village be permitted 30
days from the date of establishing residency in the village to purchase a
vehicle license.
(Ord. No. 2014-19-3371; Ord. No. 2019-08-3456)
§ 23-67 CLASSIFICATION; FEES.
   (a)   The licensing period shall begin on May 1 and shall run for one year.
Application for annual licenses may be made 45 days prior to May 1 (by March 15
each year).
   (b)   Fees for licenses shall be paid annually to the village based upon the
date such licenses are issued. The fees for motor vehicle licenses, including
penalties for late payment, are and shall be as set forth in the Comprehensive
Fee and Fine Schedule.
   (c)   Any unit of local government with authority to levy property taxes
will be exempt from fees authorized in this section.
(Ord. No. 2014-19-3371; Ord. No. 2017-1-3409)
§ 23-68 ISSUANCE.
   After payment of the fees provided for in the preceding section, the village
shall issue the license required by this article for a motor vehicle and shall
record such license in the Village’s official records.
(Ord. No. 2014-19-3371; Ord. No. 2025-04-3608)
§ 23-69 EXPIRATION.
   All motor vehicle licenses provided for in this article shall expire on
April 30 following the date of issue.
(Ord. No. 2014-19-3371; Ord. No. 2019-08-3456)
§ 23-70 TRANSFER OF LICENSE UPON SALE OF VEHICLE.
   Immediately upon the sale of any motor vehicle licensed under this article,
such license shall cease to apply to and be valid for that motor vehicle. Any
person who sells a motor vehicle license under this article may transfer such
license to a different motor vehicle upon making application to the village,
giving such information as may be required (i.e. documentation of sale) no
later than 30 days after the date of sale.
(Ord. No. 2014-19-3371; Ord. No. 2025-04-3608)
ARTICLE VI. OPERATION OF VEHICLES
§ 23-71 DRIVING ON SIDEWALKS, ETC.
   The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within any parkway or sidewalk area
except at a permanent or temporary driveway.
§ 23-72 LIMITATIONS ON TURNING AROUND.
   (a)   No driver of a vehicle shall turn such vehicle to the left upon any
street in the business district for the purpose of proceeding in the opposite
direction or for the purpose of standing, stopping or parking on such street.
   (b)   No driver of a vehicle shall turn such vehicle to the left upon any
street outside of the business district for the purpose of proceeding in the
opposite direction or for the purpose of standing, stopping or parking on such
street unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with
other traffic.
(Ord. No. 85-11-1716)
§ 23-72.1 LIMITATIONS ON RIGHT TURNS.
   Pursuant to the authority vested in the board of trustees of the village by
Ill. Rev. Stat., chapter 95 ½, § 11-208, it is hereby determined upon the basis
of an engineering and traffic investigation of the department of public works
of the village and the public safety department of the village, that right
turns at red signals after stopping as permitted by Ill. Rev. Stat. 1971,
chapter 95 ½, § 11-306, chapter 95 ½, upon all public streets be prohibited due
to potentially hazardous conflicts with vehicles or pedestrians at the
following approaches to the following intersections:
 
Intersection                  Limitation

                              approaches to this intersection
 
(Ord. No. 73-11-1508, § 1; Ord. No. 77-14-1556, § 1)
§ 23-72.2 LIMITATIONS ON TURNS WHEN PARKING.
   No driver of any vehicle shall make a left turn of such vehicle so as to
cross the center line of any street located in any area of the village zoned
for business uses for the purpose of parking on such street nor shall any such
driver turn or back such vehicle across the center line of any such street when
exiting any parking space located on any such street.
(Ord. No. 83-3-l663)
§ 23-73 DRIVING WHILE UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF ALCOHOL, OTHER DRUG OR COMBINATION
THEREOF.
   (a)   A person shall not drive or be in actual physical control of any
vehicle within this state while:
      (1)   The alcohol concentration in such person's blood or breath is 0.10
or more based on the definition of blood and breath units in the Illinois
Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/11-501.2;
      (2)   Under the influence of alcohol;
      (3)   Under the influence of any other drug or combination of drugs to a
degree which renders such person incapable of safely driving; or
      (4)   Under the combined influence of alcohol and any other drug or drugs
to a degree which renders such person incapable of safely driving.
   (b)   The fact that any person charged with violating this section is or has
been legally entitled to use alcohol, or other drugs, or any combination of
both, shall not constitute a defense against any charge of violating this
section.
   (c)   Every person convicted of violating this section or a similar
provision of a local ordinance, shall be guilty of a Class A misdemeanor and,
in addition to any other criminal or administrative action, for any second or
subsequent conviction of violating this section or a similar provision of a
local ordinance committed within five years of a previous violation of this
section or a similar provision of a local ordinance shall be mandatorily
sentenced to a minimum of 48 consecutive hours of imprisonment or assigned to a
minimum of ten days of community service as may be determined by the court. The
imprisonment or assignment shall not be subject to suspension nor shall the
person be eligible for probation in order to reduce the sentence or assignment.
   (d)   The Secretary of State shall revoke the driving privileges of any
person convicted under this section or a similar provision of a local
ordinance. Amended by P.S. 82-783, Art. III, § 37, eff. July 13, 1982; P.A. 83-
204, § 2, eff. Jan. 1, 1984.
Cross-reference:
   As to alcoholic beverages, see
ch. 4
   As to procedure when taxicab driver is guilty of drunk driving, etc., see §
32-17
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to driving under the influence of intoxicating liquor or
narcotic drugs, see Ill. Rev. Stat., ch. 95 ½, § 11-501
§ 23-74 NEGLIGENT DRIVING.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle upon a public way
negligently so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property.
Without limiting the foregoing, for purposes of this section, it shall be
presumed that a person has operated a vehicle negligently and is endangering or
is likely to endanger persons or property if such person:
   (a)   Uses a wireless telephone as defined in 625 ILCS 5/12-610.1(a) while
operating a vehicle; and
   (b)   Operates the vehicle in a manner that violates any law or regulation
governing the movement of vehicles on any public way.
(Ord. No. 2010-22-3280)
§ 23-75 RECKLESS DRIVING.
   (a)   Any person who drives any vehicle with a willful or a wanton disregard
for the safety of persons or property is guilty of reckless driving.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an act of reckless
driving within the village.
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to reckless driving, see Ill. Rev. Stat., ch. 95 ½, § 11-
504
§ 23-75.1 SPEED LIMITS - "URBAN DISTRICT" DEFINED.
   As used in §§
23-75.2 to
23-75.4, the term URBAN DISTRICT shall mean the territory contiguous to and
including any street in the village which is built up with structures devoted
to business, industry or dwelling houses situated at intervals of less than 100
feet for a distance of a quarter of a mile or more.
(Ord. No. 65-7-1432, § 1)
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to speed restrictions generally, see Ill. Rev. Stat., ch.
95 ½, §§ 11-601 et seq.
§ 23-75.2 SAME - REASONABLE AND PROPER SPEED; DECREASING SPEED UNDER CERTAIN
CONDITIONS.
   (a)   No person shall drive any vehicle upon any street in this village at a
speed which is more than is reasonable and proper with regard to traffic
conditions and the use of the street, which endangers the safety of any person
or property or is more than the applicable maximum speed limit established by
§§
23-75.3 and
23-75.4.
   (b)   The fact that the speed of a vehicle does not exceed the applicable
maximum speed limit does not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed
when approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching and going
around a curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon any narrow or
winding roadway or when special hazards exist with respect to pedestrians or
traffic or by reason of weather or highway conditions.
   (c)   Speed shall also be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding
with any person or vehicle on or entering a street in compliance with the legal
requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care.
(Ord. No. 65-7-1432, § 1)
§ 23-75.3 SAME - MAXIMUM LIMITS IN AND OUTSIDE OF URBAN DISTRICT.
   The maximum speed limit for any vehicle operated on a street in the village,
unless some other such limit is established pursuant to the provisions of §
23-75.4 or unless some other such limit is established by the state or the
county pursuant to law, is as follows:
   (a)   Outside of an urban district, the maximum is 65 mph; and
   (b)   In an urban district the maximum is 30 mph; however, in an alley the
maximum is 15 mph.
(Ord. No. 65-7-1432, § 1)
§ 23-75.4 SAME - SPECIFIC STREETS AND ZONES.

§ 11-604, 625 ILCS 5/11-601 et seq. (1998), it is hereby determined upon the
basis of engineering studies and traffic investigations of the department of
public works of the village and the public safety department of the village,
that the speed permitted by §§
23-75.2 and
23-75.3 (as well as by 625 ILCS 5/11-601 et seq.) upon the public streets,
thoroughfares, areas and zones thereof in the village hereinafter described is
more than reasonable or sound with respect to the conditions found to exist
along such streets, thoroughfares, areas and zones, and it is hereby declared
that the maximum speed limit along such streets or thoroughfares, or within
such areas or zones, shall be as herein stated, which speeds so declared shall
be effective at the times specified when signs giving notice thereof are
erected along such streets or thoroughfares, or within the areas or zones of
affected streets or thoroughfares, by the village manager or the manager's
designee:
   (a)   Maximum speed limits for specific streets.

§ 23-76 DRIVING WITH VIEW OBSTRUCTED; WHEN MIRROR REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which is so loaded or in such a
condition that the operator does not have a clear vision of all parts of the
roadway essential to the safe operation of such vehicle. Any vehicle that is so
constructed or in such condition as to obstruct the operator's view of the
roadway to the rear of such vehicle shall be equipped with a mirror so attached
that it will afford the operator a view of the roadway behind him or her.
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to mirror requirements, see Ill. Rev. Stat., ch. 95 ½, §
12-502
§ 23-77 OPERATING NOISY VEHICLE.
   It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle which makes unusually loud or
unnecessary noise.
§ 23-78 APPROACHING RAILROAD GRADE CROSSING.
   (a)   The driver of a vehicle approaching a railroad grade crossing when a
signal device gives warning of the immediate approach of a train shall stop
within 50 feet but not less than ten feet from the nearest track of such
railroad and shall not proceed until he or she can do so safely.
   (b)   The driver of a vehicle shall stop at and not traverse such grade
crossing when a crossing gate is lowered or when a flagman or automatic signal
warns of the approach of a train.
Cross-reference:
   As to railroads generally, see
ch. 27
§ 23-79 DRIVING THROUGH PROCESSIONS.
   No driving of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a
funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such
vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this chapter. This
provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by
traffic-control signals or police officers.
Cross-reference:
   As to parades and processions generally, see §§
23-6,
23-7
§ 23-80 APPROACHING AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLE.
   (a)   Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle, when
the driver is giving audible signal by siren, exhaust whistle or bell, the
driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way and shall
immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the
right-hand edge or curb of the highway clear of any intersection and shall stop
and remain in such position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed,
except when otherwise directed by a police officer.
   (b)   This section shall not operate to relieve the driver of an authorized
emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all
persons using the highway.
Statutory reference:
   For similar state law, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½, § 169
§ 23-81 APPROACHING FIRE DEPARTMENT VEHICLE.
   Upon the approach of a fire department vehicle, drivers of vehicles shall
comply with the provisions of §
23-80 relating to the approach of authorized emergency vehicles.
Cross-reference:
   As to fire department generally, see §§
2-98
§ 23-82 FOLLOWING, ETC., FIRE APPARATUS.
   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle, other than one on
official business, to follow any fire apparatus in response to a fire alarm
closer than one block, or to park any vehicle within a block where fire
apparatus has stopped to answer a fire alarm.
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to following fire apparatus, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch.
95 ½, § 193
§ 23-83 DRIVING OVER FIRE HOSE.
   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive over any
unprotected hose of the fire department without the consent of the fire
department officer in command.
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to crossing fire hose, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 95 ½,
§ 194
ARTICLE VII. STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING
§ 23-84 MANNER OF PARKING.
   (a)   Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a roadway where there is an
adjacent curb shall be so stopped or parked with the right-hand wheels of such
vehicle parallel with and within 12 inches of the right-hand curb, except for
angle parking.
   (b)   Upon those streets which have been marked or signed for angle parking,
vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such marks or
signs, with the nearest corner of the vehicle within 12 inches of the curb.
§ 23-84.1 PARKING ON SIDEWALKS, PARKWAYS AND DRIVEWAY APRONS.
   No person shall park any vehicle on any portion of a parkway, including
sidewalks and driveway aprons. Driveway aprons are defined as that portion of a
parkway connecting a private driveway and an improved roadway. Notwithstanding
the foregoing, persons may park vehicles classified as first division vehicles
pursuant to §
23-67 of this code on driveway aprons serving their own residence or residences
that they are visiting.
(Ord. No. 77-1-1543A, § 2; Ord. No. 99-12-2077)
§ 23-84.2 LIMITATIONS ON PARKING MANEUVERS.
   No driver of a vehicle shall turn such vehicle to the left upon any street
in the business district for the purpose of standing, stopping or parking along
a curb on such street regardless of whether parallel or angle parking is
otherwise permitted, and no driver of a vehicle upon any other street shall so
turn such vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety and without
interfering with other traffic.
(Ord. No. 85-11-1716)
§ 23-85 PARKING IN ALLEYS OR ROADWAYS.
   No person shall park a vehicle within an alley or on any roadway in such a
manner or under such conditions as to obstruct the roadway for the free
movement of vehicular traffic.
(Ord. No. 77-1-1543A, § 1)
§ 23-86 PARKING FOR CERTAIN PURPOSES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose
of:
   (a)   Displaying such vehicle for sale; or
   (b)   Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle for compensation, except
repairs necessitated by an emergency.
§ 23-86.1 HANDICAPPED AND MEDICAL EMERGENCY PARKING.
   (a)   (1)   It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to park a
vehicle or to leave a vehicle unattended in any area designated by the owner
thereof or the village as "handicapped parking," unless either the driver or a
passenger in the vehicle is a handicapped person or disabled veteran.
      (2)   It shall further be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to park a
vehicle or to leave a vehicle unattended in any area designated by the owner
thereof or the village as "medical emergency parking," unless either the driver
or a passenger in the vehicle is in urgent need of medical attention at the
medical office for which such space is provided.
      (3)   Any property owner reserving a portion of a parking area for
handicapped or medical emergency parking is deemed to have granted the village
the right to enforce these parking restrictions. A HANDICAPPED PERSON for the
purpose of this section shall be any person who is defined as HANDICAPPED
pursuant to Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 95-1/2, § 1-159.1, and whose vehicle possesses
handicapped license plates issued by the State of Illinois or who has obtained
a sticker for display on the vehicle from the State of Illinois to be issued to
handicapped persons.
   (b)   Notwithstanding any penalty provisions in this chapter or this code,
any person violating subsection
23-86.1(a) hereof shall be assessed a fine in the amount of not less than $250
for each offense and any such person may have his or her vehicle towed from any
parking area designated as handicapped or medical emergency parking as provided
by article X of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 96-4-2000; Ord No. 08-05-3216)
   (c)   Any property owner may reserve a portion of the owner's parking area
for handicapped or medical emergency parking, or both, by causing appropriate
signs to be posted and maintained. The village manager may reserve any village-
owned or leased parking space for handicapped or medical emergency parking, or
both, by causing appropriate signs to be posted and maintained.
   (d)   A motor vehicle bearing a sticker or registration plates issued to a
handicapped person shall be exempt from the payment of parking meter fees and
exempt from any time limitation in parking, except for limitations of one-half
hour or less on any street, road or parking lot or parking place owned or
leased by the village
(Ord. No. 85-12-1717; Ord. No. 86-10-1731)
§ 23-87 PARKING BETWEEN 2:00 A.M. AND 6:00 A.M. PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park any vehicle on any street between the hours of 2:00
a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of any day.
§ 23-87.1 PARKING PROHIBITED ON SHERIDAN ROAD.
   No person shall park any vehicle on Sheridan Road at any time without the
express permission of the village manager.
(Ord. No. 78-1-1563, § 1)
§ 23-88 AUTHORITY OF VILLAGE MANAGER - TO PROHIBIT PARKING ON CERTAIN STREETS;
PARKING IN VIOLATION OF SIGNS.
   (a)   The village manager is hereby authorized to prohibit the parking of
vehicles at all times, or between certain hours, on any street or portion of
any street when in his or her discretion such parking may impede the free flow
of traffic on such streets, and shall cause appropriate signs to be created and
maintained giving notice thereof.
   (b)   No person shall park a vehicle during the time prohibited at places so
indicated by official signs.
Cross-reference:
   As to village manager generally, see §§
2-20 to
2-27
§ 23-89 SAME - TO RESTRICT PARKING ON CERTAIN STREETS; OVERTIME PARKING.
   (a)   The village manager may designate either side, or both sides, or any
portion of either side, of any street as a restricted parking area, and shall
determine the time of the day any such parking restriction shall be effective
as well as the duration of time allowed for continuous vehicular parking, and
shall cause appropriate signs to be erected and maintained in such areas
designating the effective time of day of such parking restriction as well as
the duration of time that continuous vehicular parking is allowed. Such
designation shall be evidenced by the physical presence of such signs or
legends or notices on or near the parking lane of the streets or portions
thereof where such restrictions are to be effective.
   (b)   No person shall park a vehicle for any period of time in excess of the
time posted on the officially erected sign or legend or notice effective for
the parking space for which it is erected during the effective time thereof.
§ 23-90 LIABILITY OF PARKING REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of the
provisions of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in
whose name such vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such
violation and subject to the penalty thereof.
   (b)   For the purposes of this section, it is the intent of the president
and board of trustees of the Village of Glencoe that vicarious liability shall
be imposed upon the registered owner of the vehicle and it shall not be a
defense that someone other than the registered owner was in control of the
vehicle when the violation occurred.
(Ord. No. 78-17-1573)
§ 23-91 STANDING VEHICLE GENERALLY; STANDING FREIGHT CARRYING VEHICLE IN
LOADING ZONE.
   It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger
vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading or
unloading of passengers, not to exceed three minutes, and for the driver to
stand any freight carrying vehicle for a period of time longer than is
necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed 30 minutes, in
any place designated by the village manager as a loading zone and marked as
such.
§ 23-92 PARKING OF BUSSES AND TAXICABS.
   (a)   The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not park upon any street in any
business district at any place other than at a bus stop or taxicab stand
respectively; except, that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any
such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or
parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged
in loading or unloading passengers.
   (b)   The driver of an intercity bus shall not stop, stand, or park upon any
street in the village for the purpose of making an unscheduled stop, as defined
in Section
32-31 of this Code, to allow passengers to disembark, except that this
provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily
stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations.
(Ord. No. 2024-03-3580)
Cross-reference:
   As to taxicabs and other vehicles for hire generally, see
ch. 32
§ 23-93 USE OF BUS STOPS AND TAXICAB STANDS BY VEHICLES OTHER THAN BUSSES AND
TAXICABS.
   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus
stop, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when any such stop or stand
has been officially designated and appropriately signed; except, that the
driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily defense that someone other than
the registered owner was in control of the vehicle when the violation occurred.
(Ord. No. 78-17-1573)
Cross-reference:
   As to taxicabs and other vehicles for hire generally, see
ch. 32
§ 23-93.1 SNOW EMERGENCIES.
   (a)   No person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any
portion of any public street, highway or roadway in the village at a time when
a snow emergency, as defined in subsection
23-93.1(b) of this section, exists.
   (b)   A SNOW EMERGENCY shall exist whenever there has been an accumulation
of new snow or ice or two inches or more in any period of time of 24 hours or
less. A snow emergency shall terminate with respect to any one-block portion of
any public street, highway or roadway whenever such street area has become
substantially clear of snow and ice for the length of an entire block to a
width sufficient to allow passage of traffic in two directions.
   (c)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit parking at any
time or place where it is otherwise forbidden by another provision of law.
§ 23-93.2 PROLONGED PARKING PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle at the same
location on any public street, highway or roadway for a period of 24 or more
consecutive hours.
§ 23-93.3 ABANDONMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park, store or leave, or to
permit the parking, storing or leaving of any licensed or unlicensed motor
vehicle or part thereof upon any private property within the village for more
than seven days if the motor vehicle or part thereof, whether attended or not,
is in a discarded, wrecked, partially dismantled, inoperative or abandoned
condition. Any motor vehicle or part thereof found to be parked, stored or left
in violation of this section shall be deemed "abandoned" and subject to towing
and removal pursuant to article IX of this chapter.
   (b)   This section shall not apply to any motor vehicle or part thereof that
is parked, stored or left in a fully enclosed building.
§ 23-93.4 VIOLATIONS OF THIS ARTICLE - PENALTIES.
   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be
fined for each offense in the amount set forth in the village’s Comprehensive
Fee and Fine Schedule.
(Ord. No. 2018-09-3440)
ARTICLE VIII. BUSINESS DISTRICT PARKING
§ 23-94 DEFINITIONS.
   Whenever in this article the following terms are used, they shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section.
(Ord. No. 89-10-1803)
   COIN BOX.  A non-mechanical device located in a parking zone into which
payment can be made for parking privileges.
   DAYTIME PARKING ZONE. A parking zone designated for parking in excess of 120
consecutive minutes and located on streets or property owned by the village or
by the METRA/Union Pacific Railroad Companies and leased to the village.
   PARKING PASS. Any of various types of stickers, passes or similar devices
officially issued by the village for a designated fee that authorizes a vehicle
displaying such device to park in a daytime or standard parking zone during the
time allowed by the pass and by this article.
   PARKING ZONE. A designated and marked section of a public street or other
publicly owned or leased property within the marked boundaries of which a
vehicle may be temporarily parked and allowed to remain.
   STANDARD PARKING ZONE. A parking zone in which a vehicle may be temporarily
parked and allowed to remain for a time not to exceed 120 consecutive minutes.
   VEHICLE. Any device by which any person or property may be transported upon
a highway, except those operated upon rails or tracks, or motivated by the
power of horses or kindred animals.
(Ord. 2016-12-3402)
§ 23-95 INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF PARKING ZONES AND COIN BOXES.
   (a)   The village manager shall provide for the installation and maintenance
of parking zones and the painting of marking lines to designate the parking
spaces within which a vehicle may be temporarily parked. The village manager
shall also provide for the installation and maintenance of appropriate signage
to inform persons of any limitations in the use of such parking spaces.
   (b)   The village manager shall provide for the installation and maintenance
of coin boxes in reasonable proximity to the parking spaces for which such coin
boxes are to be used.
(Ord. 2016-12-3402)
§ 23-96 IMPROPER PARKING GENERALLY; COIN TO BE DEPOSITED IN COIN BOX; PROPER
PARKING PASS TO BE DISPLAYED.
   No vehicle parked in a parking zone shall be parked across any marking line
designating a parking space or in any position other than entirely within the
area designated by such marking lines. Failure to park entirely within such
designated area shall be a violation of this article and shall subject the
vehicle operator to the penalty prescribed by this article. When, during the
times specified in § 23-98 of this article, any vehicle shall be parked in any
parking zone requiring that a fee be deposited in a coin box, the operator of
such vehicle shall, immediately upon parking in such zone, deposit or cause to
be deposited in the coin box serving the parking space being occupied the
appropriate amount necessary for complete payment of the specified fee. Failure
to deposit the required payment for the parking space in the coin box shall
constitute a violation of this article and shall subject the vehicle operator
to the penalty prescribed by this article. When, during the times specified in
§ 23-98 of this article, any vehicle shall be parked in any parking zone
requiring that a proper parking pass be displayed, the operator of such vehicle
shall have a proper parking pass displayed upon the vehicle in the manner
prescribed for the pass. Failure to display the proper parking pass shall
constitute a violation of this article and shall subject the vehicle operator
to the penalty prescribed by this article.
(Ord. 2016-12-3402)
§ 23-96.1 SPECIFIC PROHIBITION; BUSINESS (B) PERMIT PARKING.
   (a)   Employees, independent contractors, and other persons performing work
for local businesses are prohibited from parking in the standard parking zone
during business hours, 7:00 a.m. - 5:30 p.m., and must obtain from the Village
"B Permit" parking passes and park their vehicles in designated B permit
parking areas outside the central business district.
   (b)   B Permits shall be provided by the Village on an annual basis and,
upon receipt, must be displayed on the rearview mirror and visible through the
front windshield of the vehicle.
   (c)   B Permit holders that park vehicles in the central business district,
in violation of this section, are subject to penalties as described in § 23-
102.
   (d)   In addition, at all times during which a B Permit holder is working on
behalf of the business in question, business district employers shall be
jointly and severally responsible for any of their workers' violations of this
section.
(Ord. 2016-12-3402)
§ 23-97 MAXIMUM PARKING TIME PERMITTED; PARKING FEES; OVERTIME PARKING.
   (a)   Standard parking zone. Upon parking a vehicle in a parking space
located in a standard parking zone, such vehicle shall be permitted to occupy
such parking space for not more than the time period posted, or, if no time
period is posted for such parking space, not more than 120 consecutive minutes.
   (b)   Daytime parking zone. Upon displaying a proper parking pass in a
daytime parking zone as required by § 23-96, the parking space may be lawfully
occupied until required to be vacated pursuant to § 23-98 of this article.
Subject to the approval by motion of the board of trustees, the village manager
shall from time to time establish a schedule that designates the fees and
duration for parking passes then in effect.
   (c)   Overtime parking. Except as provided in § 23-98 of this article, if
any vehicle shall remain in any parking zone beyond the time limits herein
established, or without payment of the fees herein specified, such vehicle
shall be considered to be parked overtime in violation of this article and the
owner or operator thereof shall be subject to the penalties set forth in this
article.
(Ord. No. 2001-15-3032; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394; Ord. 2016-12-3402)
§ 23-98 DESIGNATION OF “OVERNIGHT” DAYTIME PARKING ZONES.
   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle or permit a vehicle to remain
parked in any daytime parking zone between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m.
on any day. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the village manager may, in his or
her discretion, designate certain daytime parking zones as “overnight” daytime
parking zones so as to allow overnight parking within such parking zones;
provided, however, that in no event may any vehicle remain in a designated
“overnight” daytime parking zone for a period of more than 48 consecutive
hours. Designated "overnight" daytime parking zones are located in the Temple
Court municipal parking lot, the South East commuter parking lot, and the off-
street parking spaces on the west side of Greenwood between Hazel and Park
Avenues.
(Ord. No. 2001-15-3032; Ord. No. 2016-12-3402)
§ 23-98.1 RESERVED.
§ 23-99 PARKING LONGER THAN MAXIMUM TIME PERMITTED.
   In any standard parking zone, no person shall park in a parking space for
longer than the time period posted, or, if no time period is posted for such
parking space, for longer than 120 minutes.
(Ord. No. 2001-15-3032; Ord. No. 2016-12-3402)
§ 23-100 TAMPERING WITH COIN BOXES PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the board of trustees
to deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the
usefulness of any coin box installed or maintained under the provisions of this
article.
(Ord. No. 2016-12-3402)
§ 23-101 DEPOSITING SLUGS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited in
any coin box a slug or any other fraudulent substitute for a coin or currency
of the United States.
(Ord. No. 2016-12-3402)

shall be fined for each offense as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee
and Fine Schedule.
(Ord. No. 98-3-2046; Ord. No. 06-14-3156; Ord. No. 08-05-3216; Ord. No. 2014-

   The fees required to be deposited in coin boxes and to be collected for
issuing parking passes as provided in this article are hereby levied and
assessed to provide for the proper regulation and control of traffic upon the
public streets and in parking zones; for the cost of the supervision and
regulation of the parking of vehicles in parking zones; for the cost of
purchasing, leasing, acquiring, installing, operating, maintaining,
supervising, regulating and controlling the coin boxes and parking zones
described herein, or such other facilities as are now or may hereafter be

parking zone.

   This article shall be deemed to be an additional and supplementary provision
for the regulation of traffic and parking in parking zones and not in conflict
with other ordinances of the village.
