ARTICLE I. STATEMENT OF PURPOSE AND GOALS
§ 26B-1 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to promote the recognition of structures,
buildings, objects, sites, and areas in the village having historic and
architectural interest and value. The village seeks to recognize such
structures, buildings, objects, sites, and areas in order to encourage their
protection, enhancement, and perpetuation for the benefit of the village and
its residents because of their significance to the village's archaeology,
history, culture and architecture.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§ 26B-2 GOALS.
   This chapter is created in order to:
   (a)   Foster civic pride in the beauty and accomplishments of the past as
represented in the village's honorary landmarks and recognized historic areas;
   (b)   Encourage the preservation, promotion and maintenance of the village's
historic resources;
   (c)   Encourage the protection and enhancement of the village's
attractiveness to residents, visitors and prospective homebuyers;
   (d)   Encourage the maintenance and improvement property values in the
village;
   (e)   Encourage the protection, preservation and enhancement of the
village's aesthetic appearance and character;
   (f)   Encourage the conferring of honorary landmark and recognized historic
area status upon structures, buildings, objects and sites on a local level; and
   (g)   Educate the general public as to the significance of historic
preservation.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
ARTICLE II. DEFINITIONS
§ 26B-3 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, certain words, phrases and terms, shall be
construed as set forth in this article.
   ADDITION.  Any act or process that changes the exterior architectural
appearance of a structure by adding to, joining with or increasing the size or
capacity of the structure.
   ADVISORY REVIEW. The procedure established in article V of this chapter to
consider plans for the alteration or demolition of either a structure,
building, object or site having honorary status as provided under this chapter.
   ALTERATION. Any act or process other than demolition that changes the
exterior architectural appearance of any structure, building, object or site
having honorary status, including without limitation the erection,
construction, reconstruction, addition, repair, rehabilitation, removal,
restoration or relocation of any structure.
   AREA. A specific geographic division of the village.
   BOARD OF TRUSTEES. The president and board of trustees of the Village of
Glencoe.
   BUILDING. A structure having a roof that is supported by columns or walls
for the shelter, support or enclosure of persons, animals or chattels.
   COMMISSION. The Glencoe historic preservation commission.
   COMMISSIONERS. The members of the commission.
   CONSTRUCTION. The act of adding an addition to, reconstructing or otherwise
altering an existing structure or the act of erecting a new principal or
accessory structure on a site.
   DEMOLITION. Any act or process that destroys a structure, building or object
in whole or in part to the extent of 50% of its volume.
   DESIGN GUIDELINES. Standards of appropriate activity that will preserve the
historic and architectural appearance and character of a structure, building,
object, site or area.
   EXTERIOR ARCHITECTURAL APPEARANCE.  The architectural character, general
composition and general arrangement of the exterior of a structure, building,
object or site, including without limitation the kind, color and texture of the
building material and the type, design and character of all windows, doors,
light fixtures, signs and appurtenant elements.
   HISTORIC DISTRICT. An area established as a recognized historic area under
this
chapter 26B or a certified historic district under chapter 26A of the village
code.
   HONORARY LANDMARK. A structure, building, object and/or site established as
An honorary landmark by ordinance duly passed and published by the board of
trustees pursuant to this
chapter 26B which has a special character or historical and/or architectural
interest or value as part of the development, heritage or culture of the
village, the State of Illinois or the United States, and as such is worthy of
preservation, restoration and/or rehabilitation. Any structure, building,
object or site identified as a Landmark by the United States Secretary of
Interior in the National Register of Historic Places or by the Illinois
Director of Conservation in the Illinois Register of Historic Places shall also
be an honorary landmark as defined herein (unless such landmark has been
certified pursuant to
chapter 26A of the village code).
   HONORARY STATUS. A structure, building, object, site, or area that has been
approved pursuant to this
chapter 26B as an honorary landmark or a recognized historic area, or any
structure, building, object, site, or area within a certified historic
districts (as provided for in
chapter 26A of this code) for which no declaration has been signed or recorded
as provided in
chapter 26A.
   LANDMARK. A structure, building, object and/or site established as an
honorary landmark or a certified landmark.
   LANDMARK, CERTIFIED. A landmark established through the certification
procedures set forth in
chapter 26A of the village code.
   OBJECT. A material or natural thing of functional, architectural, cultural,
historical, aesthetic or scientific value that may be, by nature or design,
movable yet related to a specific setting or environment.
   RECOGNIZED HISTORIC AREA. An area established as a recognized historic area
by ordinance duly passed and published by the board of trustees pursuant to
this chapter 26B and which may contain within definable geographic boundaries
one or more honorary landmarks or certified landmarks (as established pursuant
to
chapter 26A of the village code) and which may have within its boundaries other
structures, buildings, objects or sites that, while not of such historic and/or
architectural significance to be identified as landmarks, nevertheless
contribute to the overall visual characteristics of the landmark or landmarks
located within such historic area. Any area identified as an Historic
Preservation District by the United States Secretary of Interior in the
National Register of Historic Sites and Places shall also be an recognized
historic area as defined herein (unless otherwise granted certified status
pursuant to
chapter 26A of the village code).
   REHABILITATION. The process of returning a structure, building, object or
site to a state of utility, through repair, construction or alteration, which
makes possible an efficient contemporary use while preserving those portions
and features of the property which are significant to its historic,
architectural and cultural values.
   RELOCATION. The process of moving a structure, building or object on its
site or to another site.
   RESTORATION. The process of restoring, repairing or reconstructing a
property, through repair, construction or alteration, to a former or original
condition that enhances those portions and features of the property that are
significant to its historic, architectural and cultural values.
   SITE. A single lot or parcel of property.
   STRUCTURE. Anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires
permanent or temporary location on or in the ground or attached to something
having a permanent location on or in the ground.
   VILLAGE. The Village of Glencoe.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§ 26B-4 INTERPRETATION.
   Unless specifically defined herein, words or phrases in this chapter shall
be interpreted so as to give them the same meaning as they have in common usage
and so as to give this chapter its most reasonable application.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
ARTICLE III. HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
§ 26B-5 COMMISSION TO IMPLEMENT.
   The commission as established under article III of
chapter 26A of the village code shall implement the provisions of this
chapter 26B except as otherwise expressly provided.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§ 26B-6 VOTE REQUIRED.
   The affirmative vote of at least three commissioners shall be required to
recommend that a structure, building, object, site or area be recognized as an
honorary landmark, or be established as a recognized historic area. Any
advisory review conference may be conducted by a subcommittee of the commission
consisting of no fewer than three commissioners.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§ 26B-7 ADDITIONAL AUTHORITY AND DUTIES.
   In addition to the commission's authority and duties as set forth in
chapter 26A, and subject to the laws of the State of Illinois, the Glencoe
village code and any other ordinances and resolutions of the village, the
commission shall have and may exercise the additional authority and duties
herein described:
   (a)   To assist persons in the preparation of an application for recognition
as an honorary landmark or for a recognized historic area and the alteration or
demolition of the same;
   (b)   To hold public hearings, review applications, conduct advisory review
conferences, make recommendations or decisions regarding the recognition of a
structure, building, object and/or site as an honorary landmark or a recognized
historic area, the alteration or demolition of the same;
   (c)   To keep a register of all structures, buildings, objects, sites and
areas that have been approved as an honorary landmark, or a recognized historic
area, including all information required for the approval of each landmark or
district;
   (d)   To determine an appropriate design of markers for honorary landmarks
and recognized historic areas.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§§ 26B-8 - 26B-19 RESERVED.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
ARTICLE IV. ESTABLISHMENT OF LANDMARKS AND HISTORIC DISTRICTS
§ 26B-20 CRITERIA.
   The commission shall consider the criteria set forth in section
26A-20 of the village code in order to recommend a structure, building, object
or site for approval as an honorary landmark, or an area for approval as a
recognized historic area.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§ 26B-21 REVIEW AND APPROVAL PROCEDURES,
   (a)   Nominations. Nominations for approval as an honorary landmark or a
recognized historic area may be submitted by a commissioner, the owner of the
nominated site, or 50% or more of the owners of property within an area to be
nominated.
   (b)   Preliminary review. Prior to submitting a complete application for
honorary landmark or recognized historic area approval, an applicant may
request the commission to conduct a preliminary review of whether a structure,
building, object, site or area could qualify as an honorary landmark or
recognized historic area. An applicant can seek preliminary review by
submitting a request therefor to the village clerk that includes at least the
information required in either §
26B-21(c)(1)A.1. through 7., or §
26B-21(c)(1)B.1. through 7., as applicable, and any other information that the
applicant wishes to provide. The commission may then review the information and
advise the applicant of its preliminary recommendation regarding honorary
landmark or recognized historic area status based on the information provided.
These preliminary review procedures shall be informal and shall not bind either
the applicant or the commission in any way.
   (c)   Application.
      (1)   The application for nomination shall include as least the following
information and specifications:
         A.   For an honorary landmark.
            1.   Applicant's name and address;
            2.   Owner's name and address;
            3.   Street address, legal description or real estate index number
(s) of the site;
            4.   A written statement describing the structure, building, object
or site and setting forth reasons in support of the requested approval;
            5.   Written documentation that the owner or occupant has been
notified of or consents to the requested approval of landmark status;
            6.   Brief description of the structures, buildings and objects on
the nominated site and the structures, buildings and objects on sites adjacent
to and across from such site; and
            7.   Whatever additional materials the commission requests.
         B.   For a recognized historic area.
            1.   Applicant's name and address;
            2.   Owners' names and addresses;
            3.   A vicinity map delineating the boundaries of the area
nominated for approval as a recognized historic area;
            4.   A written statement describing the area and the structures,
buildings, objects and sites located therein and setting forth reasons in
support of the establishment of a recognized historic area;
            5.   Written documentation that the owners or occupants have been
notified of or consent to the proposed establishment of a recognized historic
area;
            6.   Brief description of the structures, buildings, objects and
sites in the nominated area and the structures, buildings, objects and sites,
adjacent to and across from such area; and
            7.   Whatever additional materials the commission requests.
      (2)   Complete application forms shall be filed with the village clerk,
who shall forward each application to the commission and its secretary for
action.
   (d)   Notice. Within 15 days after the filing of a nomination on a completed
application form, the secretary of the commission shall schedule a public
hearing on the whether such application should be recommended for approval by
setting forth a date, time and place for such hearing. Such hearing shall be
scheduled for the next available regular meeting of the commission. The
secretary of the commission shall cause written notice to be sent to the
applicant, the owner or owners of record, the occupants (either by name or to
"occupants" of the site or sites in question), and, if known, to other persons
having a legal or equitable interest in the site or sites nominated for
landmark or historic district status and shall also cause notice to be
published in a newspaper of general circulation in the village. Such notice
shall be given not less than 15 days prior to the scheduled hearing and shall
set forth the nature of such hearing, the site or area involved, and the date,
time and place of such hearing. If, upon diligent search, the identity or
whereabouts of the owner or owners of record or legal or equitable interest
holders is not ascertainable, notice mailed to the person or persons in whose
name such site was last assessed is sufficient notice under this chapter.
   (e)   Public hearing. At the public hearing, the commission shall afford all
persons present an opportunity to be heard and to express their views
pertaining to the nomination for landmark or historic district status. The
secretary of the commission shall record these proceedings. The commission may
adjourn or continue such public hearing without further public notice.
   (f)   Recommendations.
      (1)   The commission shall review all information presented to it at the
public hearing and shall adopt a recommendation that the nominated honorary
landmark or recognized historic area does or does not meet the criteria herein
prescribed. The recommendation shall be accompanied by a report that shall
contain the following information:
         A.   The commission's rationale for recommending either approval or
rejection of the nomination;
         B.   In the case of a nominated honorary landmark meeting the criteria
for honorary status, the significant feature of features in the exterior
architectural appearance of the landmark that should be protected and
preserved;
         C.   In the case of a nominated recognized historic area meeting the
criteria for honorary status, the significant features in the exterior
architectural appearance of any structures, buildings, objects or sites within
the recognized historic area that should be protected and preserved; and
         D.   Any other pertinent comments related to the nomination of the
honorary landmark or recognized historic area.
      (2)   The commission shall submit its recommendations on each nomination
to the board of trustees, which shall promptly act upon such recommendation.
All recommendations by the commission shall be filed with the village clerk and
made available to persons requesting the same in writing.
   (g)   Establishment of honorary status. An ordinance passed by the
affirmative vote of at least four members of the board of trustees shall be
required to approve an honorary landmark or a recognized historic area. Upon
passing an ordinance approving the nomination for honorary status, the board of
trustees shall direct that notice be sent to the building official, the owners
of record, the occupants (either by name or to "occupants" of the site or sites
in question), and, if known, to other persons having a legal or equitable
interest in the approved site or sites, advising them of such approval and
informing them that any structure, building, object, site or area receiving
such honorary status pursuant to this chapter shall thereafter be subject to
the requirements of this chapter. The board of trustees shall also direct that
the ordinance approving such honorary status be recorded in the office of the
Cook County Recorder of Deeds.
   (h)   Denial of honorary status. An applicant whose nomination for a
honorary status is denied by the board of trustees may request reconsideration
by filing a written request within ten days after a decision denying the
application is rendered; provided, however, that the board of trustees shall
reconsider a nomination only if substantial new evidence or information
regarding the nominated honorary landmark or recognized historic area is
provided. Once a nomination has been denied by the board of trustees, no
further nominations involving any site whose nomination was denied may be filed
for 90 days.
   (i)   Stay of proceedings. No building, demolition, sign or other permit
shall be issued for a proposed landmark or a structure, building, object, site
or area in a proposed recognized historic area from the date when the
nomination form is filed with the village clerk until the final disposition of
the nomination unless the advisory review is completed pursuant to article V of
this
chapter 26B.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§ 26B-22 WITHDRAWAL OF HONORARY STATUS.
   (a)   Conditions for withdrawal. The approval of a structure, building,
object, site or area as an honorary landmark or as a recognized historic area
(or a part thereof) may be rescinded, and such honorary status withdrawn, under
any of the following conditions:
      (1)   The structure, building, object, site or area has ceased to meet
the criteria for honorary status because the qualities which caused it to be
originally approved have been lost or destroyed or such qualities were lost
subsequent to nomination, but before the conferral of honorary status;
      (2)   Additional information shows conclusively that the structure,
building, object, site or area does not possess sufficient significance to meet
the criteria for conferral of honorary status;
      (3)   The original conferral of honorary status was clearly in error; or
      (4)   There was prejudicial procedural error in the process of reviewing
an application for honorary status.
   (b)   Requests for withdrawal. Any commissioner, the owner of any structure,
building, object or site approved as an honorary landmark, or 50% or more of
the property owners in an area approved as a recognized historic area may
initiate a procedure to withdraw the honorary status from such structure,
building, object, site or area.
   (c)   Application and hearing. A procedure to withdraw the honorary status
from a structure, building, object, site or area shall be initiated by filing
an application in accordance with subsection
26B-21(c) hereof. Upon the filing of a completed application, notice shall be
given and a public hearing shall be held in accordance with subsections
26B-21(d) and (e) hereof.
   (d)   Recommendation; determination.
      (1)   Promptly after the close of the public hearing, the commission
shall either:
         A.   Determine that withdrawal of honorary district status is not
warranted, which determination shall be final; or
         B.   Recommend to the board of trustees that the honorary status
should be withdrawn.
      (2)   Such determination or recommendation shall be in writing and shall
set forth the reasons therefor. Any determination or recommendation shall be
submitted to the board of trustees, sent to the applicant and filed with the
village clerk.
   (e)   Board action. The board of trustees shall promptly act upon a
recommendation for withdrawal of honorary status. An ordinance passed by the
affirmative vote of at least four members of the board of trustees shall be
required to rescind the approval of, and withdraw the honorary status of a
structure, building, object, site, or area (or part of a recognized historic
area). Upon passing an ordinance approving the withdrawal of such honorary
status, the board of trustees shall direct that notice be sent to the building
official, the owners of record, the occupants (either by name or to "occupants"
of the site or sites in question), and, if known, to other persons having a
legal or equitable interest in the site or sites, advising them that such
honorary status has been withdrawn. The board of trustees shall also direct
that the ordinance withdrawing the honorary status from a structure, building,
object, site or area be recorded in the office of Cook County Recorder of
Deeds.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
ARTICLE V. ADVISORY REVIEW
§ 26B-30 ADVISORY REVIEW.
   (a)   Unless expressly exempted herein, no permits for the alteration,
demolition, signage or any other physical modifications of an honorary landmark
or a structure, building, object, site or area located within a recognized
historic area or otherwise having honorary status may be issued by the village
without the commission conducting an advisoiy review in accordance with the
procedures and criteria specified in this article.
   (b)   An advisory review shall not be required in connection with:
      (1)   Permit applications not involving any alteration to or demolition
of the exterior architectural appearance of a structure, building, object or
site having honorary status; or
      (2)   Permits necessary for compliance with a lawful order of the
village, including without limitation, any permit necessary to correct what is
determined by the issuing officer to be an immediate health or safety problem;
provided such order expressly exempts the alteration or demolition from the
advisory review procedure; and provided further that such order may be made
subject to appropriate conditions to advance the purpose and goals of this
chapter.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§ 26B-31 PROCEDURE.
   (a)   Initiation. Within five days after the filing of an application for a
building, demolition, sign or other permit, the building official shall advise
the applicant of the advisory review and shall forward a copy of such
application together with plans pertaining thereto to the commission.
   (b)   Advisory review conference. Upon receipt of an application from the
building official, the commission shall consider the extent to which the
proposed alteration or demolition may be consistent or inconsistent with the
purpose and goals of this chapter and the criteria described in section
26B-32. If the commission determines that the proposed alteration or demolition
adversely affects the purpose and goals of this chapter, the commission shall
request a conference with the permit applicant. The commission shall transmit
its concerns and recommendations to the permit applicant at the time such
request is made, and the commission and the permit applicant shall use such
conference to reach a mutually satisfactory resolution of the commission's
concerns. If the commission determines, either with or without a conference,
that the proposed alteration or demolition will not adversely affect the
purpose and goals of this chapter, the commission shall inform the building
official of such a determination, and the application shall be evaluated
strictly on its merits under village building codes and regulations.
   (c)   Time for review.
      (1)   Except as provided in subsection
26B-31(d) hereof, not sooner than 120 days after filing an application for a
demolition permit, and not sooner than 35 days after filing an application for
a building, sign or other permit, for a building, structure, object, site or
area having honorary status, a permit applicant may notify the commission and
building official in writing that it no longer intends to participate in the
advisory review process.
      (2)   Upon receipt of such notice, and notwithstanding any determination
of the commission, the building official shall evaluate the application
strictly on its merits under village building codes and regulations.
   (d)   Extension of time for advisory review.
      (1)   Any delay in conducting an advisory review conference resulting
from an applicant's inability or failure to attend any conference shall extend
the time before which such applicant can conclude its participation in the
advisory review process.
      (2)   In addition to any other extension, upon request of the commission
and written notice to the permit applicant, the board of trustees may consider
and grant an extension of the time for review of an application for a
demolition permit not exceeding an additional 30 days if the board determines
that the commission's efforts to preserve a structure, building, object, site
or area having honorary status will promote the public welfare without causing
undue hardship on the permit applicant.
   (e)   Other laws and. regulations. The advisory review shall not negate,
modify or supersede other laws or regulations regarding structural and fire
safety.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§ 26B-32 CRITERIA.
   In conducting an advisory review, the commission shall consider the criteria
described in section
26A-53 of the village code, as applicable.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§§ 26B-33 - 26B-39 RESERVED.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
ARTICLE VI. FINANCIAL BENEFITS
§ 26B-40 INTENT.
   It is the express intention of the board of trustees that this
chapter 26B not be considered for, nor presented to the Illinois Historic
Preservation Agency for consideration for, certification by the Illinois
Historic Preservation Agency or the United States Department of the Interior.
Additionally, it is the express intention of the board of trustees that the
conferral of honorary status shall not qualify structures, buildings, objects
or sites as an "historic building" under the Revenue Act, 35 ILCS 200/10-40 et
seq. or as a "certified historic structure" under the Tax Reform Act of 1986,
26 U.S.C. §§ 1 et seq. or under other legislation subsequently passed into law
by the State of Illinois or the United States. The village manager or the
manager's designee shall cooperate with the Illinois Historic Preservation
Agency (or any other department or officials providing or overseeing the
granting of financial benefits in furtherance of historic preservation) to
effect the intent of this chapter as set forth in this section
26B-40.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§§ 26B-41 - 26B-49 RESERVED.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
ARTICLE VII. RESERVED
§§ 26B-50 - 26B-59 RESERVED.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
ARTICLE VIII. GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 26B-60 VIOLATIONS.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to
the penalty provisions of
chapter 16 of the Glencoe village code. In addition, the village may seek to
enforce the provisions of this chapter by suit or action seeking injunctive or
other judicial relief.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
§ 26B-61 INTERPRETATION.
   This chapter is not intended to repeal, abrogate, annul or in any way impair
or interfere with any existing provision of law or ordinance or any rules,
regulations or permits; provided, however, that where there is a conflict
between any provision of this chapter and provisions of any other law or
ordinance, the provision that imposes a greater restriction upon the use of
buildings or premises shall control. Any structure, building, object or site
established as a "Designated Landmark" under
chapter 26A of the village code on or before March 21, 2013 shall remain a
"Designated Landmark" but shall hereafter be construed as an "Honorary
Landmark" for purposes of
chapters 26A and
26B.
(Ord. No. 2013-10-3340)
CHAPTER 27: RAILROADS

27-1   Definitions
   
27-2   Crossings to be kept in repair

27-5   Protective gates, personnel, etc., at crossings
   
27-6   Obstruction of crossings
   
27-7   Right-of-way fences - required; approval of fencing
   
27-8   Same - notice to install, repair, etc.
   
27-9   Duty of railroads as to streets, etc., in which tracks are laid
   
27-10   Permission required to make certain deposits on streets; loading and
unloading on streets restricted; erections, etc., of structures on streets
   
27-11   Placing tracks, etc., on streets, etc. - generally
   
27-12   Same - flying, etc., switches prohibited
   
27-13   Removal of prohibited tracks and appurtenances
   
27-14   Village may require track elevation
   
27-15   Drainage of rights-of-way and adjacent property
   
27-16   Headlights and backing lights
   
27-17   Sounding whistle
   
27-18   Information as to violations
Charter reference:
   For charter provision as to authority of village in connection with
regulations, etc., of railroads, etc., see char.,
art. IV, § 30
Cross-reference:
   As to vehicle approaching railroad grade crossing, see §
23-78
Statutory reference:
   As to railroads generally, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 114
   For state law as to authority of village in connection with railroad safety,
see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 24, 1 11-57.1
§ 27-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
   CROSSING. Any intersection of railroad right-of-way with any street, alley,
highway or other public thoroughfare in the village.
   RAILROAD. Any railroad or railway firm, company or corporation and any owner
or lessee of a railroad track.
§ 27-2 CROSSINGS TO BE KEPT IN REPAIR.
   Every railroad within the village shall keep its crossings, and the
approaches thereto, in good repair to the satisfaction of the village manager.
(1929 Code, § 696)
§ 27-3 NOTICE TO REPAIR CROSSING - DUTY OF VILLAGE MANAGER.
   When it shall appear to the village manager that any railroad crossing in
the village is out of repair, he or she shall forthwith give notice to the
railroad to repair the same.
(1929 Code, § 696)
§ 27-4 SAME - TIME FOR COMPLIANCE.
   Every railroad receiving notice to repair a crossing pursuant to the
preceding section shall comply with such notice within 48 hours thereafter.
(1929 Code, § 696)
§ 27-5 PROTECTIVE GATES, PERSONNEL, ETC., AT CROSSINGS.
   (a)   Every railroad whose tracks shall cross any street, alley or highway,
shall install and maintain, on each side of the tracks, gates that shall
provide protection against injury to persons and property at such crossings.
Each such pair of gates shall at all times open and close simultaneously. Such
gates shall be operated day and night.
   (b)   Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to require the
construction or maintenance of such gates at any crossing provided with a
subway or viaduct of such a nature that the public is not required to cross the
tracks at grade.
   (c)   Every gate, guard, viaduct, subway and the approaches thereto, or
other protection connected with or adjacent to any railroad in the village,
shall be installed at the sole cost and expense of the railroad company, under
the supervision of the village board of trustees or its agent and shall
thereafter be kept and maintained by such railroad in proper repair and
condition at its own cost and expense and without cost or expense to the
village.
(1929 Code, § 700)
§ 27-6 OBSTRUCTION OF CROSSINGS.
   (a)   No railroad locomotive engine, car or train shall stop in or remain
upon any crossing within the village for a period longer than five minutes at
any one time, under a penalty of $10 for each and every consecutive five
minutes any such locomotive engine, car or train shall be permitted to so
remain in or upon such crossing; provided, however, that in case a wreck should
take place at any such crossing, reasonable time shall be allowed to remove any
obstruction that may be caused by such wreck.
   (b)   Should any crossing in the village remain obstructed, in whole or in
part, by any train for and during the period of five minutes, it shall be the
duty of the railroad, on or before the expiration of five minutes, when from
any cause the entire train cannot be propelled or removed to any one side of
such crossing, to cause such cars as may be on or near such crossing to be
uncoupled and the obstructing cars to be removed from the crossing and leave
the crossing entirely clear. When the train is again coupled it shall be
removed from such crossing immediately.
(1929 Code, § 706)
§ 27-7 RIGHT-OF-WAY FENCES - REQUIRED; APPROVAL OF FENCING.
   Every railroad shall fence its right-of-way within the village with a
substantial fence, to be approved by the village president.
(1929 Code, § 697)
Cross-reference:
   As to fences generally, see §§
9-74 to
9-81
§ 27-8 SAME - NOTICE TO INSTALL, REPAIR, ETC.
   The village president shall notify any railroad that has neglected or
refused to erect any fence required by the preceding section, or has suffered
the same to fall into decay or out of repair, to erect or repair such fence
within ten days from the date or receipt thereof. Such railroad shall comply
with such notice.
(1929 Code, § 697)
§ 27-9 DUTY OF RAILROADS AS TO STREETS, ETC., IN WHICH TRACKS ARE LAID.
   All railroads shall raise or lower their railroad tracks lying within the
village so as to conform to any grade which may at any time be established for
any street, alley or highway by ordinance of the village. Where such tracks run
across or lengthwise on any such street, alley or highway, they shall keep
their railroad tracks on a level with the surface, and keep such streets in
good order, so that such tracks may be crossed at any place in such street,
alley or highway. Where such tracks cross any street, alley or highway, they
shall keep the same planked between the rails.
(1929 Code, § 708)
§ 27-10 PERMISSION REQUIRED TO MAKE CERTAIN DEPOSITS ON STREETS; LOADING AND
UNLOADING ON STREETS RESTRICTED; ERECTIONS, ETC., OF STRUCTURES ON STREETS.
   No railroad shall deposit or place in any street, alley or highway any car,
engine, wagon, lumber, wood, coal or other material except by the written
permission of the board of trustees. No railroad shall load or unload any car
from or upon any street, alley or highway except by the written permission of
the board of trustees. No railroad shall erect or maintain any switchhouse or
other building upon any street, alley or highway within the village, except by
the written permission of the board of trustees.
(1929 Code, § 708)
§ 27-11 PLACING TRACKS, ETC., ON STREETS, ETC. - GENERALLY.
   No tracks, sidings, side tracks, switch tracks, turnouts, frogs, switches or
rails shall be placed in or across any portion of a street, alley or highway
without special permission from the board of trustees.
(1929 Code, §§ 702, 703)
§ 27-12 SAME - FLYING, ETC., SWITCHES PROHIBITED.
   No running or flying switches shall be permitted along or across any street,
alley or highway.
(1929 Code, §§ 702, 703)
§ 27-13 REMOVAL OF PROHIBITED TRACKS AND APPURTENANCES.
   The president of the village is hereby authorized to remove immediately any
tracks, sidings, side tracks, switches or switching tracks and other
appurtenances which may be laid in violation of the two preceding sections.
(1929 Code, § 703)
§ 27-14 VILLAGE MAY REQUIRE TRACK ELEVATION.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to affect the right of the
village at any time to require any railroad to elevate its tracks within the
village.
(1929 Code, § 104)
§ 27-15 DRAINAGE OF RIGHTS-OF-WAY AND ADJACENT PROPERTY.
   All railroads shall make and keep open and in repair ditches, side drains,
sewers and culverts along and under their tracks, so that filthy and stagnant
water cannot stand on their grounds or rights-of-way and in such manner that
the natural drainage of the adjacent property shall not be impeded.
(1929 Code, § 698)
§ 27-16 HEADLIGHTS AND BACKING LIGHTS.
   Every locomotive engine, railroad car or train running at night in the
village shall have and keep while so running a brilliant and conspicuous light
on its forward end. If such engine, car or train is backing, it shall have a
conspicuous light in the rear car or engine so as to show the direction in
which it is moving.
(1929 Code, § 707)
§ 27-17 SOUNDING WHISTLE.
   (a)   No railroad shall cause or allow the whistle of any locomotive engine
to be sounded within the village except necessary signals for brakes and
crossings and such as may be absolutely necessary to prevent injury to persons
and to property; except, that locomotives operating through the village shall
sound warning signals between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m.
(1929 Code, § 709) (Ord. No. 1273; Ord. No. 1419, § 1)
   (b)   Notwithstanding the restriction contained in §
27-17A of this code, commencing on September 1, 2005, no railroad shall cause
or allow the whistle of any locomotive engine to be sounded within the village
at any time of the day, except necessary signals for brakes and crossing and
such as may be absolutely necessary to prevent injury to persons and to
property.
(Ord. No. 2005-16-3136)
§ 27-18 INFORMATION AS TO VIOLATIONS.
   Each superintendent of any railroad shall furnish to any officer of the
village applying therefor the name of any person in the employment of such
railroad who shall have been charged with having violated any of the provisions
of this chapter.
(1929 Code, § 710)
CHAPTER 28: RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX
Section
   
28-1   Imposed; amount
   
28-2   Reports required
   
28-3   Payments to State Department of Revenue
Charter reference:
   For charter provision as to taxation generally, see char.,
art. V, §§ 1 to
8
Statutory reference:
   For Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax Act, see Ill. Rev. Stat., ch. 24, §
8-11-1
§ 28-1 IMPOSED; AMOUNT.
   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the village in the
business of selling tangible personal property at retail, at the rate of 1% of
the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while
this chapter is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of chapter 24, §
8-11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code.
(Ord. No. 69-3-1468, § 1)
§ 28-2 REPORTS REQUIRED.
   Every such person engaged in such business specified in §
28-1 in the village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar
month, the report to the State Department of Revenue required by § 3 of "An Act
in Relation to a Tax upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible
Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption," approved June 28,
1933, as amended.
(Ord. No. 69-3-1468, § 2)
§ 28-3 PAYMENTS TO STATE DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE.
   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State
Department of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the
receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month.
(Ord. No. 69-3-1468, § 3)
CHAPTER 29: SCAVENGERS
Section
   
29-1   License - required; application; issuance
   
29-2   Same - investigation of applicant; inspection of vehicles
   
29-3   Same - fee
   
29-4   Regulations generally
   
29-5   Vehicles generally
§ 29-1 LICENSE - REQUIRED; APPLICATION; ISSUANCE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of scavengers,
or to collect or remove garbage, rubbish or offal, without having first secured
a license therefor. Applications for such licenses, and the issuance thereof,
shall comply with the provisions of
chapter 22 relating to licenses.
(1929 Code, § 549)
Cross-reference:
   As to licenses and permits generally, see
ch. 22
§ 29-2 SAME - INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; INSPECTION OF VEHICLES.
   Upon the receipt of any application for a license required by §
29-1, the village manager shall make or cause to be made an investigation into
the character of the applicant. No license shall be issued to any person who is
not a person of good character, nor to any company whose officers are not
persons of good character. The village manager shall inspect or cause to be
inspected all vehicles intended to be used by the applicant, and shall not
issue a license unless these vehicles comply with the provisions of this code
and other ordinances of the village.
(1929 Code, § 550)
§ 29-3 SAME - FEE.
   The annual fee for scavengers' licenses plus each vehicle used for the
business shall be as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine
Schedule.
(1929 Code, § 551) (Ord. No. 1223; Ord. No. 1406, § 10; Ord. No. 90-3-1812;
Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 29-4 REGULATIONS GENERALLY.
   All persons doing business as scavengers in the village shall be fully in
compliance with all provisions of this code and other ordinances relating to
the business, or relating to traffic or to the movement of vehicles on the
streets. Care shall be taken when removing any garbage or offal that no waste
material is permitted to fall or remain on any premises. It is unlawful to
employ as driver of any vehicle or as helper therefor any person who is not a
person of good character.
(1929 Code, § 553)
§ 29-5 VEHICLES GENERALLY.
   All vehicles used by scavengers in the conduct of their business shall be
kept in a sanitary condition. The body or box of such vehicle shall be
waterproof, and each vehicle shall be equipped with a suitable cover.
(1929 Code, § 552)
Cross-reference:
   As to motor vehicles and traffic generally, see
ch. 23

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
§ 30-1 SUPERVISION, ETC.
   (a)   All streets, sidewalks, alleys and public ways in the village shall be
under the supervision of the village manager.
   (b)   He or she shall have general charge of the construction and all other
work done on such places, shall superintend the cleaning thereof; and shall see
to the enforcement of all provisions of this code and other ordinances and laws
relating thereto.
(1929 Code, §§ 186, 208, 220)
§ 30-2 REPAIRS - GENERALLY.
   (a)   All public streets and sidewalks in the village shall be kept in good
repair.
   (b)   Repairs shall be made by order of the village manager and shall be
supervised by him or her.
(1929 Code, § 187)
§ 30-3 SAME - BARRICADES, ETC., FOR REPAIRING OR LAYING PAVEMENTS.
   (a)   Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or
other public place, shall maintain suitable barricades and warning signals to
prevent injury to any person by reason of the work, and shall have the
barricades lighted at night.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful to disturb any such barricade without proper
authority.
(1929 Code, §§ 187, 209, 244) (Ord. No. 1312A)
§ 30-4 SAME - PAVEMENT DEFECTS - OFFICIALS TO REPORT.
   It shall be the duty of every village official or employee to report to the
village manager every defect observed in the pavement of any street or
sidewalk.
(1929 Code, § 188)
§ 30-5 SAME - SAME - ACTION BY VILLAGE MANAGER.
   It shall be the duty of the village manager either to repair the defects
reported pursuant to the preceding section promptly, or to report the same to
the board of trustees, after just properly barricading the same so as to avoid
injury to any vehicle, person or animal.
(1929 Code, § 188)
§ 30-6 INJURING STREETS, ETC.; INTERFERING WITH STREET DRAINAGE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or do any injury to any
sidewalk, street, alley or other public place in the village in any manner, or
to interfere with the drainage of any street.
(1929 Code, § 240)
§ 30-7 PUBLIC DISPLAY OF MERCHANDISE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, sidewalk or other
public place as a place for the display or sale of goods or merchandise of any
kind.
(1929 Code, § 242)
§ 30-8 DEPOSITING CERTAIN ARTICLES ON STREETS, ETC., PROHIBITED.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful to cast, throw or propel any missile on any
street, alley or public place or to throw or deposit any glass, nails, tacks or
other similar articles on any street, sidewalk or alley in the village.
   (b)   In addition to the above, it shall also be unlawful for any person to
deposit on any street or sidewalk any material which may be harmful to the
pavement or any waste material, or anything which might cause injury to any
animal, vehicle or person.
(1929 Code, §§ 189, 777)
§ 30-9 PLAYING GAMES.
   It shall be unlawful to play any games on any street or sidewalk in the
village.
(1929 Code, § 224)
Cross-reference:
   As to use of coaster, roller skates, etc., on streets, see §
23-12
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to authority of village to prevent and regulate use of
streets for amusements, see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 24, § 11-80-9
ARTICLE II. SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION
§ 30-10 APPLICABILITY OF ARTICLE TO CERTAIN WORK.
   The provisions of this article shall not apply to sidewalks which are laid
by the village or by the board of local improvements.
(1929 Code, § 210)
§ 30-11 PERMIT - REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   It shall be unlawful to construct or lay the pavement for any public
sidewalk within the village without having first obtained a permit therefor.
Applications for such permits shall be made in writing to the village manager
and shall comply with the general provisions relating to applications for
permits as set forth in
chapter 22.
(1929 Code, § 203)
§ 30-12 SAME - TO CONTAIN SPECIFICATIONS, ETC.
   The permit required by §
30-11 shall incorporate the plans and specifications for the sidewalk to be
constructed according to its terms.
(1929 Code, § 207)
§ 30-13 BOND.
   All persons making applications pursuant to §
30-11 shall file a bond in the penal sum of $3,000, conditioned to save the
village harmless from any injury to any person or property which may be caused
by the construction of a sidewalk.
(1929 Code, § 205)
§ 30-14 COMPLIANCE WITH OFFICIAL PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS.
   All sidewalks constructed in the village shall be constructed in accordance
with plans and specifications approved from time to time by the president and
board of trustees. It shall be unlawful to deviate in any material way from the
plans and specifications for a sidewalk incorporated pursuant to §
30-12 in the permit therefor required by this article.
(1929 Code, § 207)
§ 30-15 WIDTH OF SIDEWALKS.
   All sidewalks shall be five feet in width, unless specific provision to the
contrary is made authorizing the construction of a particular sidewalk.
(1929 Code, § 206)
ARTICLE III. DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION AND ALTERATION
§ 30-16 COMPLIANCE WITH ARTICLE REQUIRED.
   No person shall construct, build, establish or maintain upon any public
thoroughfare a driveway from any property abutting such public thoroughfare to
the pavement along such public thoroughfare, or use any portion of such parkway
for a private drive, except in compliance with and under the terms of this
article.
(1929 Code, § 212) (Ord. No. 1392, § 1)
§ 30-17 PERMIT GENERALLY; FEE.
   Any person desiring to construct or alter any private driveway referred to
in the preceding section shall make application for a permit therefor to the
village manager and shall pay a permit fee as set forth in the village’s
Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule. No construction or work of any kind shall
be done or permitted on such proposed driveway until and unless such permit is
duly applied for and issued. Upon the receipt of such application upon the
forms prescribed by the village manager, if the same shall be found to be in
accordance with the terms of this article, and on the payment of such permit
fee, the village manager shall issue such permit, subject to the conditions and
terms of this article.
(Ord. No. 80-11-1611; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 30-18 DEPOSIT REQUIRED.
   On the issuance of a permit under the provisions of this article, the
applicant therefor shall deposit with the village manager a sum as set forth in
the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule as guarantee that the work
under such permit shall be in accordance with the terms of this article. When
such work is completed and shall have been duly found to be in accordance with
this article and shall have been done to the satisfaction of the village
engineer or the village manager, such deposit shall be refunded. If, during the
progress of such work, it shall be determined by the village manager that such
construction work is not in accordance with this article, the applicant
thereupon shall be directed to make such changes and remedy such work as shall
ensure the work to conform to this article within such time and upon the
conditions prescribed by the village. If within such time the work is not
completed according to the directions prescribed by the village, then the
village shall cause the work to be changed and remedied so that the same shall
be in accordance with this article and the expenses and costs thereof shall be
deducted from the deposit and the balance thereof, upon the completion of such
work, shall be returned to the applicant.
(Ord. No. 80-11-1611; Ord. No. 2014-05-3357; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 30-19 NUMBER OF DRIVEWAYS ALLOWED.
   (a)   The village manager on receiving an application for a driveway permit
may issue a permit for the construction of one driveway to any one lot or
parcel of land concerning which such application shall have been made.
   (b)   The village manager shall, in his or her discretion, upon application
as aforesaid, issue a permit for one additional driveway to any lot or parcel
of land concerning which such application shall have been made or issue a
permit for two additional driveways to any corner lot or corner parcel of land
concerning which such application shall have been made, if, upon investigation,
he or she shall find that the construction and maintenance of such additional
driveway or driveways shall not substantially impair, endanger or interfere
with the public safety.
   (c)   In exercising such discretion the village manager shall consider the
amount of pedestrian and vehicular traffic on the proposed driveways and on the
street or sidewalk adjacent to the property sought to be connected with any
street or thoroughfare. He or she shall also consider the grade or elevation of
the public street with which any such driveways are to be so connected to any
street intersection, railroad or railway crossing, fire or police station or
school or church.
(1929 Code, § 215) (Ord. No. 1392, § 1; Ord. No. 1425, § 1)
§ 30-20 PROCEDURE WHEN PERMIT DENIED.
   In the event the village manager, in his or her discretion, shall refuse to
issue a permit for a driveway, his or her action in so refusing such permit
shall be subject to review by the board of trustees. If the board of trustees
finds that the construction and maintenance of any such driveway will not
substantially impair, endanger or interfere with the public safety, it shall by
resolution direct the issuance of any such permit for a driveway of such width
and at such location as to the board of trustees shall be considered proper and
in furtherance of public safety; otherwise a permit shall not be issued.
(1929 Code, § 216) (Ord. No. 1392; § 1)
§ 30-21 WIDTH AND LOCATION OF DRIVEWAYS.
   Each driveway permitted under this article shall be of such grade and of
such width, not exceeding 16 feet at the lot line and sidewalk, and shall be
constructed in accordance with driveway plans and specifications on file in the
office of the director of public works at such location as the village manager
in his or her discretion shall find proper after making the investigation in
the light of the standards specified in the preceding section.
(1929 Code, § 217) (Ord. No. 1392, § 1)
§ 30-22 MATERIAL REQUIREMENTS.
   Driveways connecting with paved streets shall be paved with bituminous
surface, portland cement concrete or other comparable hard surface pavement, in
accordance with plans and specifications on file in the office of the director
of public works. A bituminous surface shall have a minimum depth of one inch
without any loose material on top and shall have a base of water bound macadam
at least six inches in depth. Portland cement concrete driveways shall be at
least six inches in depth and shall be constructed of concrete containing one
part of portland cement, two parts sand and four parts crushed stone or gravel,
on a compact base. That portion of any driveway that crosses any concrete
sidewalk shall be constructed of portland cement concrete six inches thick.
(Ord. No. 1392, § 1)
§ 30-23 GRADE REQUIREMENTS.
   That portion of a driveway that crosses a sidewalk shall be kept as nearly
as possible at the same grade as the walk, so as to avoid interference with
pedestrian traffic. No steps shall be created in the sidewalk because of any
driveway construction, and at no time shall the gradient of the sidewalk that
crosses a driveway exceed one foot vertical to ten feet horizontal. The
established grade at the gutter or street level shall not be changed by the
driveway, and no part of the driveway shall extend beyond the curb or street
line in such a manner as to change the grade of the gutter or street or
obstruct the free flow of water in the gutter. Where elevations or depressions
are necessary in the parkway strip between the curb or street and the sidewalk
or property line, the parkway shall be graded on both sides of the driveway to
a distance sufficient to create a gradual ascent or descent. At no time shall
the gradient exceed one foot vertical to ten feet horizontal.
(Ord. No. 1392, § 1)
§ 30-24 REMOVAL OF CURBS.
   Combined curb and gutter and separate curbing shall be entirely removed for
the full width of the driveway opening at the curb line. Any such curb removal
shall be done so as to avoid any injury to the curb remaining in place, which
shall be rounded off and finished under the supervision of the village manager
or his or her representative.
(Ord. No. 1392, § 1)
§ 30-25 DRAINAGE.
   No driveway shall be so constructed so to interfere with the drainage of the
adjoining street, or so as to permit the forming of pools of water in the
driveway.
(Ord. No. 1392, § 1)
§ 30-26 BARRIERS AND LIGHTS REQUIRED.
   Adequate barriers and lights shall be maintained whenever any sidewalk is
obstructed by construction of a driveway, to prevent injury to any pedestrians.
(Ord. No. 1392, § 1)
§ 30-27 TEMPORARY DRIVEWAYS.
   It shall be lawful to establish a temporary driveway for the conveyance of
vehicles across any parkway or sidewalk when no regular driveway is
established; provided, that a permit therefor is obtained from the village
manager. Such temporary driveway shall be properly planked so that the parkway,
sidewalk and curb are adequately protected from injury.
(Ord. No. 1392, § 1)
ARTICLE IV. EXCAVATIONS AND TUNNELS
§ 30-28 COMPLIANCE WITH ARTICLE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation in any street,
parkway, alley or public place, or to tunnel under any street, parkway, alley
or public place in the village without complying with the regulations set forth
in this article.
(1929 Code, § 192) (Ord. No. 1314)
§ 30-29 EXCAVATION AND TUNNELING PERMIT - REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation in any street,
parkway, alley or public place, or to tunnel under any street, parkway, alley
or public place in the village without having obtained a permit therefor.
(1929 Code, § 192) (Ord. No. 1314)
§ 30-30 SAME - APPLICATION.
   Applications for permits required by the preceding section shall be made to
the village manager, and shall state thereon the location of the intended
excavation or tunnel, the size thereof, the purpose thereof, the person doing
the actual excavating, and the name of the person for whom the work is being
done.
(1929 Code, § 193) (Ord. No. 1314)
§ 30-31 SAME - FEE.
   The fee for permits required by this article to make any excavation or
tunnel shall be not less than the amount set forth in the village’s
Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule for excavation that does not exceed 60
square feet in area, plus an amount as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive
Fee and Fine Schedule for each additional ten square feet or fraction thereof.
The village manager may from time to time publish revised fee amounts for such
permits to ensure that such permit fees are reflective of the costs to the
village relating to such street openings.
(1929 Code, § 194) (Ord. No. 1314; Ord. No. 90-3-1812; Ord. No. 06-08-3150;
Ord. No. 2014-05-3357; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 30-32 BOND.
   Each person applying for an excavating or tunneling permit pursuant to the
provisions of this article shall also file a bond conditioned that he or she
will suitably guard or protect any excavation or obstruction maintained or
created by him or her, and will indemnify the village for any loss or damage
resulting from injury to any person caused by such excavation or obstruction.
(1929 Code, § 194) (Ord. No. 1314)
§ 30-33 PERMIT TO USE MECHANICAL POWER DRIVEN EXCAVATING, ETC., EQUIPMENT -
REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation in any street,
parkway, alley or public place or to grade or disturb the surface of any
street, alley, parkway or public place or to tunnel under any street, parkway,
alley or public place in the village by means of any mechanical power driven or
operated machine without first having obtained a permit to use such machine for
such purpose.
(1929 Code, § 192) (Ord. No. 1314)
§ 30-34 SAME - APPLICATION.
   Application for a permit to use a mechanical power driven or operated
machine as required by §
30-33 shall be made to the village manager, and shall state thereon the size
and type of machine to be used, the location of the intended excavation, tunnel
or grading, the size thereof, the purpose therefor, the name of the person
doing the actual excavating, tunneling or grading and the name of the person
for whom the work is being done.
(1929 Code, § 193) (Ord. No. 1314)
§ 30-35 SAME - FEE.
   The fee for permits to use any mechanical power driven or operated machine
for the purpose of excavating or tunneling or grading shall be as set forth in
the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule in addition to the fee levied
by §
30-31.
(1929 Code, § 194) (Ord. No. 1314; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 30-36 BARRICADES AND LIGHTS.
   Sufficient and proper barricades and lights shall be maintained to protect
persons, vehicles and animals from injury by or because of an excavation or
tunnel being made under the provisions of this article.
(1929 Code, § 1965) (Ord. No. 1314)
§ 30-37 WORK TO BE DONE IN ACCORDANCE WITH PERMIT AND APPLICATION.
   Any person making any excavation or tunnel shall do so according to the
terms and conditions of the application and permit authorizing the work to be
done.
(1929 Code, § 195) (Ord. No. 1314)
§ 30-38 RESTORING STREET, ETC. - GENERALLY.
   Any person making any excavation or tunnel in or under any street, alley or
public place in the village shall restore such street, alley or public place to
its original condition, except for the surfacing that shall be done by the
village, promptly upon the completion of the work for which the excavation or
tunnel was made.
(1929 Code, § 196) (Ord. No. 1314)
§ 30-39 SAME - WHEN VILLAGE TO CARRY OUT RESTORATION.
   In case of any unreasonable delay in carrying out the requirements of the
preceding section, the village manager shall give notice to the permittee that
unless the excavation or tunnel is refilled properly and the surface relaid so
as to be in the same condition it was prior to the excavation within ten days,
the village will do the work and charge the expense of doing the same to such
person. If at the end of the time mentioned the conditions of the notice have
not been complied with, the work shall be done by the village, and accurate
account of the expense involved shall be kept, and the total cost shall be
charged to the person who made the excavation or tunnel.
(1929 Code, § 196) (Ord. No. 1314)
ARTICLE V. PARKING CUTOUT CONSTRUCTION
§ 30-40 "PARKING CUTOUT" DEFINED.
   As used in this article, the term PARKING CUTOUT shall mean a space, located
on any public thoroughfare adjacent to a village pavement, used primarily for
the parking of vehicles.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-41 CONSTRUCTORS OR USERS TO COMPLY WITH ARTICLE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, to construct upon any street, avenue,
alley, parkway or public thoroughfare within zones A, B, C and D of the
village, as defined in the zoning ordinance, a parking cutout, or to use any
portion of such street, avenue, alley, parkway or public thoroughfare for a
parking cutout, except in compliance with and under the terms of this article.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-42 PERMIT - REQUIRED.
   Any person desiring to construct a parking cutout on any public thoroughfare
shall first obtain a permit therefore from the village manager. No construction
or work of any kind shall be done on such cutout until the permit required by
this section has been issued.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-43 SAME - APPLICATION.
   Application for the permit required by the preceding section shall be made
to the village manager on forms prescribed by him or her.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-44 SAME - FEE.
   The fee for the permit required by §
30-42 shall be as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine
Schedule.
(Ord. No. 1323; Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 30-45 SAME - ISSUANCE.
   If the application submitted under §
30-43 shows conformance with the terms of this article, the village manager
shall, upon payment of the required fee, issue a parking cutout construction
permit.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-46 SAME - REVOCATION.
   Parking cutout construction permits shall be revocable at the will of the
village manager.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-47 CASH CONSTRUCTION AND RESTORATION DEPOSIT - GENERALLY.
   On the issuance of the permit required by §
30-42 and prior to the commencement of any construction thereunder, the
applicant therefor shall deposit with the village manager the sum of $100 as a
guarantee that the work under such permit shall be in accordance with the terms
of this article and that upon the termination of the permit the area covered by
the cutout will be restored to the condition existing prior to its
construction.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-48 SAME - USE ON TERMINATION PERMIT.
   If the permit issued under this article is terminated by the village, the
deposit made with the village manager provided for in the preceding section
shall be used to restore the parkway to the condition existing prior to its
construction; provided, that the person placing the deposit with the village
fails to restore the parkway in accordance with the provisions of this article
within nine days.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-49 MAINTENANCE.
   The person placing the deposit required by §
30-47 with the village shall be responsible for maintaining the parking cutout
in a condition satisfactory to the village manager.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-50 SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)   A parking cutout shall be constructed according to the following
specifications, the details of which are on file in the office of the director
of public works.
   (b)   The construction work shall consist of a seven-inch water bound
macadam base and a two-inch State Department of Public Works and Buildings,
Division of Highways, specification known as "bituminous concrete dense fine-
graded aggregate type, subclass I-II" surface.
   (c)   If a curb exists along the edge of the existing pavement across the
location of the proposed parking cutout, the existing curb shall be removed and
a new curb shall be constructed to separate the parking cutout from the
parkway. The curb to be constructed shall be 18 inches in depth, six inches
wide at its upper surface, and eight inches wide at its base. The upper surface
adjacent to the parking cutout shall be rounded at the top to a radius of three
inches. The parking cutout curb shall be connected to the present street curb
with two curves having radii of three feet. This curb shall be constructed of
portland cement concrete containing one part of portland cement, two parts sand
and four parts crushed stone or gravel.
   (d)   The parking cutout shall be no longer than 38 feet either at the
existing curb line or at the gutter line of the existing pavement and shall be
no wider than eight feet measured perpendicular to the present street pavement.
   (e)   Where no curbs exist at the gutter line, the lines of the parking
cutout shall conform to the curb lines as stated in this section.
   (f)   The elevation of the pavement of the parking cutout at the gutter line
of the street shall conform to the elevation of the existing pavement at the
gutter line, and in no case shall the parking cutout be constructed in such a
way as to block, retard or change the direction of any flow of water that might
at any time reach such gutter.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-51 NUMBER OF CUTOUTS PERMITTED PER RESIDENCE; CUTOUTS PROHIBITED UNDER
CERTAIN CIRCUMSTANCES.
   Only one parking cutout per residence shall be permitted on any public
thoroughfare. No parking cutout shall be permitted on a public thoroughfare
having a pavement width of more than 20 feet. No parking cutout shall be
permitted that would interfere with or obstruct in any way any village public
improvement, such as water main, hydrant, sidewalk, manhole, catch basin or
sign; that would necessitate removing any trees; or that would create a hazard
or endanger the public safety.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-52 CONTINUANCE OF EXISTING NONCONFORMING CUTOUTS.
   Any parking cutout constructed and in use prior to May 24, 1954, which does
not conform with the conditions of this article may be continued subject to
termination at any time on order of the board of trustees, and such parking
cutout may be reconstructed or altered only in accordance with and in
compliance with the provisions of §
30-50.
(Ord. No. 1323)
§ 30-53 VARIANCES FROM ARTICLE.
   The president and board of trustees may, after notice and public hearing,
waive the payment of fees and the making of deposits and permit the
construction of a parking cutout and authorize a variance in its location,
shape or size whenever such parking cutout is to be adjacent to any premises
used for municipal, park, school or church purposes upon a finding that such
variance is reasonably necessary for the public convenience or welfare, and
with respect to other cutouts when it is found that there are practical
difficulties or particular hardships in the way of carrying out the strict
letter of this article.
(Ord. No. 1323)
ARTICLE VI. OBSTRUCTIONS, PROJECTIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS
§ 30-54 AWNINGS AND PROJECTING SIGNS.
   (a)   All movable awnings shall be elevated at least seven feet at the
lowest part of the main wood frame thereof and not less than six feet six
inches at the lowest part of the covering above the top of the sidewalk. They
shall be supported without posts, by an iron bracket or by an iron framework
attached firmly to the building. The bracket or other device for the purpose
used and the method of attaching same to the building shall be such as to clear
the heads of pedestrians at the building line, leave the sidewalk wholly
unobstructed, ensure the safety of pedestrians, and shall be subject to
approval of the director of public works. All movable awnings not heretofore
erected in the manner prescribed in this section shall be removed within a
reasonable time after notice.
(Ord. No. 95-12-1982)
   (b)   Consistent with the safe and unimpeded use of public rights-of-way,
projecting signs that have been authorized by special use permit pursuant to §
4-103F of the zoning code, projecting signs that are authorized pursuant to §
5-1051 of the zoning code, and fixed awnings may be authorized to extend over
the public right-of-way upon such terms and conditions as the village manager
establishes; provided, however, that the terms and conditions of any such
authorization shall be set forth in a written license agreement in which the
licensee shall indemnify and hold the village harmless with respect to such
authorization. Such authorization shall be in the nature of a revocable
license.
(Ord. No. 95-12-1982; Ord. No. 07-28-3205)
§ 30-55 STREET, ETC., OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED GENERALLY; REMOVAL BY VILLAGE
MANAGER.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct in any way any street, alley
or sidewalk, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. The village manager
is authorized to remove any obstructions in any such place.
(1929 Code, § 241)
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to authority of village to prevent and remove obstructions,
etc., upon streets, etc., see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 24, § 11-80-3
§ 30-56 PROJECTIONS, SIGNS, ETC., FROM BUILDINGS, ETC.
   (a)   Except as otherwise permitted by §
30-54 of this code, no person shall place or suspend or cause or permit to be
placed or suspended from any building, structure, lot or place any goods, wares
or merchandise whatever, or signs or advertisements or rigid canopies or
awnings of any kind or any other thing so that the same shall project or extend
from the wall, front or side of any such building, structure, lot or place
into, over or upon any public street, alley or sidewalk.
   (b)   The provisions and regulations of this section shall not apply to such
educational, charitable, civic, religious or governmental signs in accordance
with the following standards and as may be approved by the village manager:
      (1)   Erected in a safe and secure manner; and
      (2)   Erected so as not to constitute a traffic hazard because of size,
shape, color, position or wording.
(Ord. No. 95-12-1982)
§ 30-57 CONSTRUCTION, MAINTENANCE, ETC., OF STONES, SIDEWALK APPROACHES, ETC. -
PROHIBITED GENERALLY; EXCEPTION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, construct, maintain or control
or assist in placing, constructing, maintaining or controlling upon any street,
avenue, alley, parkway or public thoroughfare within the village any stones,
boulders, stepping stones, sidewalk approaches, flagstones or any obstructions
or barricade of any kind whatever, except as authorized and provided in this
article.
(1929 Code, § 232)
§ 30-58 SAME - MANNER OF CONSTRUCTING, ETC., SIDEWALK APPROACHES OR FLAGSTONES.
   Any person owning, using or controlling any property fronting or abutting
upon any street, avenue, alley, parkway or public thoroughfare of the village
may whenever and as permitted and authorized to do so by a permit therefor as
provided for in §
30-60, duly issued by the village, place, construct or maintain sidewalk
approaches or flagstones extending from the sidewalk line or from the lot line
to the curb line where curbs exist at the time of such construction; provided,
that the same shall be placed or maintained at an elevation not exceeding the
level of such curb at that place, or extending from the sidewalk line or the
lot line to the outside line of the pavement or roadway of such thoroughfare
where no curbs exist at the time such construction; provided, that the same
shall be placed or maintained at a level not exceeding four inches above the
edge of the pavement or roadway at that place.
(1929 Code, § 233)
§ 30-59 SAME - MANNER OF CONSTRUCTING, ETC., STONES, BOULDERS OR OTHER HARD
MATERIAL SUBSTANCES.
   Any person owning, using or controlling any property, fronting or abutting
upon any street, avenue, alley or public thoroughfare of the village may,
whenever and as permitted and authorized to do so by a permit therefor as
provided for in §
30-60, duly issued by the village, place, construct or maintain stones,
boulders or other hard material obstructions of like character in the parkway
of any public thoroughfare along and parallel with the curb line or gutter line
of any roadway in such public thoroughfare; provided, that the same shall be so
placed that they shall not be nearer than two feet from such curb line or
gutter line; and, provided further, that they shall be so placed that they
shall not extend more than four inches above the surface of the ground
adjoining their location as herein specified. For the purposes of this section,
the term GUTTER LINE shall be construed to mean the edge of the pavement or
roadway where no curb exists.
(1929 Code, § 234)
§ 30-60 PERMIT FOR PLACING, CONSTRUCTING, MAINTAINING, ETC., STONES, SIDEWALK
APPROACHES, ETC.
   Any person desiring to place, construct, maintain or control any sidewalk
approaches, flagstones, stones, boulders or other hard material obstructions of
like character in the parkway of any public thoroughfare adjoining or abutting
a property owned or controlled by him or her, shall first make application for
a permit therefor, which application shall be upon forms provided therefor by
the village manager, and shall set forth the location of the property so owned
or controlled and the details or character of the work or installation desired
to be made under this section. Such application shall be submitted to the
village manager for his or her approval or recommendation. If the same is
approved by the village manager, a permit therefor shall be issued by him or
her in the name of the village. It is a condition of all applications and
permits issued under this section that the work of construction of any such
installation or improvement under this section shall be made only upon plans
and specifications that have the approval of the engineer of the village or the
village manager. All applications hereunder shall be accompanied by a payment
as set forth in the village’s Comprehensive Fee and Fine Schedule, which fee
shall be paid into the village treasury for general use on the issuance of the
permit.
(1929 Code, § 235) (Ord. No. 2016-04-3394)
§ 30-61 REMOVAL OF UNAUTHORIZED STONES, SIDEWALK APPROACHES, ETC.
   (a)   The village manager is hereby authorized and directed to cause the
removal of any stones, boulders, stepping stones, sidewalk approaches,
flagstones or other obstructions or barricades which may be placed,
constructed, maintained or existing in any public thoroughfare in any place or
manner not authorized and permitted by the terms of this article.
   (b)   For the purpose of such removal, the village manager is authorized and
directed to employ, if necessary or expedient in his or her opinion, the
several members of the police department or fire department to assist him or
her in the necessary work of such removal.
   (c)   Prior to the removal of any such obstruction the manager shall cause
to be mailed to the owner, occupant or person in control of the property
immediately adjoining or abutting the public thoroughfare where such
obstruction to be removed is located, notifying him or her that the same must
be removed within a specified time, not less than five days from the date of
such notice.
   (d)   If the obstruction is not so removed by such owner, occupant or person
in control of such premises within the time specified, the village manager is
hereby authorized and directed to immediately remove the same as herein
provided.
   (e)   In the event of such removal, such owner, occupant or person in
control of such premises shall reimburse the village for its expenses and if
the same is not paid within a reasonable time the cost and expense of such
removal shall constitute a claim and demand against such owner, occupant or
person in control of such premises, and shall be recovered in a suit therefor
in the name of the village.
(1929 Code, § 236)
§ 30-62 DEPOSITING COAL OR OTHER MATERIALS PREPARATORY TO DELIVERY.
   Coal or other materials may be deposited in the streets preparatory to
delivery; provided, that such deposit does not reduce the usable width of the
roadway at the point to less than 18 feet; and provided further, that such
material or coal is not permitted to remain on the street for a longer period
than three hours.
(1929 Code, § 189)
§ 30-63 BUILDINGS OR STRUCTURES ENCROACHING ON PUBLIC STREETS OR PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any building or structure which
encroaches on any public street or property; except, that the board of trustees
by resolution may authorize, after due notice and public hearing, any
structure, deemed by the board of trustees to be an ornamental feature, to
encroach upon or project over any public street or property a maximum of eight
inches; provided, that such structure is a part of the remodeling of a building
in place on April 20, 1953.
(1929 Code, § 243) (Ord. No. 1312A)
Statutory reference:
   For state law as to authority of village to prevent, etc., encroachments,
etc., upon streets, etc., see Ill. Rev. Stat. 1963, ch. 24, § 11-80-3
ARTICLE VII. NUMBERING BUILDINGS
§ 30-64 REQUIRED.
   It is hereby made the duty of the owner, agent or person in possession of
every building in the village to number it in the manner provided in this
article.
(1929 Code, § 198)
§ 30-65 BASE LINES DESIGNATED; STARTING NUMBERS; DIRECTIONS OF NUMERICAL
INCREASE.
   (a)   All lots or houses located on the north and south streets and on all
streets running in a northerly and southerly direction shall be numbered from a
line passing through the intersection of the south village boundary line and
the west line of Green Bay Road and at right angles to the right-of-way of the
Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company as a base line, beginning with No. l
at such base line and increasing toward the north.
   (b)   All lots or houses located on east or west streets or on streets
running in an easterly and westerly direction shall be numbered from a line
3,000 feet easterly from and parallel with the westerly line of the right-of-
way of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company, exclusive of station
grounds, as a base line, beginning with No. l at such base line and increasing
towards the west.
(1929 Code, § 199)
§ 30-66 ASSIGNMENT OF NUMBERS.
   (a)   There shall be assigned to each 1,000 feet of street frontage 100
building numbers. The even building numbers on the north and south streets or
streets running in a northerly or southerly direction shall be on the westerly
sides of such streets and the odd numbers on the opposite sides thereof. The
even building numbers on the east and west streets or streets running in a
westerly or easterly direction shall be on the south sides of such streets and
the odd numbers on the opposite sides thereof.
   (b)   The village clerk shall assign or caused to be assigned to each lot or
house its proper number and shall inform the owner, agent or person on
possession of such premises as to the number thereof at any time upon demand.
(1929 Code, § 200)
§ 30-67 SIZE, LEGIBILITY AND PLACEMENT OF NUMBERS.
   Each of the figures of every building number required by this article shall
be not less than three inches in height, being so marked as to be easily read.
Such numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous place of the side of the house
nearest to the street.
(1929 Code, § 201)
ARTICLE VIII. SNOW REMOVAL
(Ord. No. 90-3-1812)
§ 30-68 DEFINITION.
   The term SNOW REMOVAL as used in this article is hereby defined as and shall
be construed to mean plowing or removing ice or snow by the use of a snowplow
